Very lengthy aftertaste following a medium, somewhat oily body and moderate, somewhat lively carbonation. Overall, my kind of porter. Very dry and roasty with a nice, piney hop presence. Solid, creamy chocolate flavor to balance too. This was highly enjoyable.
caramel, bread, roasty, black, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish,

Totally black, Light brown head, soft and creamy, moderate duration. Dark aroma, coffee, roasted, cerials. Flavor is sweet, light bitter finish, more coffee, faijt laqurice. Strong. Creamy texture and soft carbonation.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours black with a thick lingering tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts.  This beers chocolate and coffee flavor are very strong for a beer with an average texture.  A hint of porter smokiness.  Great beer.

Bottle purchased from Tiffanys in Kalamazoo, Mich.  Tastes of dark roast and bitter chocolate.  Its also a bit metallic, like tinfoil on a cavity.  I think a little age would do this beer well.  But, I dont mean to get down on this beer too much.  Truly, this is a good beer.

12 ounce bottle, its about a year and a half old, if not older.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with an inch and half brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, and some burnt/charred malt.  Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but the roasted and burnt malt flavor is the strongest, along with the addition of some smoke.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its creamy and has decent carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and goes down easy.  I like this brew a lot, its definitely one of my favorite Dark Horse beers!  Aging it certainly hasnt hurt it at all, either.

Pour from a 12 oz blttle. Deep are brew with rather thin brown head. Aroma of burnt malt, coffee, sweet malt, dark fruit. Flavor is dominated by burnt malt, sweet bitter chocolate, burn coffee, and sweet dark fruits. Very creamy and full mouthfeel. Lingering burnt malt at the end of the swallow. Great stuff.

11/14/10 notes: bottle.  Pours rich black with a nice lasting tan head.  Aroma is initially wet coffee rinds and ashy malt, a touch soured when first poured from bottle.  Mouthfeel has a creaminess to it that interests longer than the lightweight body would suggest.  Flavor really opens with initial ash and bakers chocolate bitterness, soon melding with sexy underlying fudge and almost a hint of dark cherry.  Deep long lasting flavor that never ventures far from the initial roast-ash bitterness.  Great bold stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick black and oily with a large dark brown head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was toasty, woody and roasty. The flavor was dry, roasty and woody with light notes of coffee, cocoa and vanilla. The finish was long, dry and roasty with some lingering vanilla. Thick and smooth body. Well done.

Bottle. Quite black, brown head. Coffee, dark chocolate aroma, a hint rust. 
Medium body, fine sparkly. Honey roasted almonds, dark chocolate and coffee, a hint lactic sourness. Smoky chocolate retronasal. Pleasant.

pours black with a small dark brown head.  strong aroma of wood, coffee, roasted malts, char, and fruity esters are abundant.  Taste is of strong roasted malt, coffee, sweet caramel, licorice, raisins. Medium to full body and the carbonation lends some bite but not too bitter in the finish.  Really full of flavor.  I could stand it to be more viscous and a little less carbonated but not that big of deal.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is chocolate and roasted malt. Pretty basic, but very inviting. 

The flavor is more of the same - roasted malt and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

There is nothing really special about the beer, but it is a very solid porter.

Pours deep dark brown/black.  Light brown, thin head, moderately quick to dissipate.  I would have labeled this an imperial stout.  Aroma is of coffee and roast.  Flavor is predominantly coffee with yummy chocolate and bitterness lying a bit beneath that.  Delicious and pretty big.  Oily.
Very solid and satisfying porter, plenty of flavor and taste, good mocha/coffee taste to it, ABV not noticeable, great pour and color, worht trying indeed.

Bottle. Dark oily brown pour with a soapy tan head that dissipates to film on top. Aroma is big creamy chocolate and espresso along with earthy malt scents. Taste is chocolate and coffee with some licorice and spice and hops. Palate is full fizzy and finishes dry. This is very good and will enjoy more!

Nice black pour with a good looking, though rather small brown head. The aroma has lots of both sweetness and roast. A lot of caramel and toffey, and a wort-ish sweetness, grainy too, some good latte coffee notes, sweet chocolate.
The taste has a delicate sweetness that reminds me of blueberries and strawberries, maybe even raspberries, a good coffee bean bitterness, cocoa powder bitterness, very creamy, has a mouthfeel a bit as a milk stout. Wow, this is a really good porter.

Bottle courtesy Josh (thanks!).  Good looking beer in the glass with an intially healthy,  burnt coffee/brown head.  Excellent roasted chocolate malt aroma with a touch of underlying sweetness.  Smells like you would expect a kick ass, roasty porter to smell.  Wow!  Damn tasty roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and the mellowest lingering roastiness as the fniish winds down - very clean.  A "must try" if you like porters.

Bottle. Pours an almost pitch black color with a slight amount of reddish notes in the bottom of the glass, and a small tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts and grains, vanilla, slight alcohol, coffee and chocolate. Flavor starts out bitter and mildly hoppy. Then roasted and burnt malts, coffee, chocolate and slight dark fruit. Body is medium with a slightly oily mouthfeel. Overall a pretty good Porter (or as the brewery calls it: Strong Black Ale) from Dark Horse!

12 oz bottle purchased at the Four Firkins in St Louis Park, Minnesota. Pour is hazed black, with a nicely formed one inch darker khaki head. Aroma is fresh malt, freshly lightly roasted coffee, along with a bright aroma. Clean and fresh. Taste picks up some on the roastiness, very much a roasty malt, along with the pine, which is sharper than it was in the nose. As it warms, it takes on more of a coffee flavor, and its sort of an office coffee taste which detracts some. Finish is dry and mineral. Clean. Palate is thin bodied, active carbonation and the bone dry roasty bright hop finish. Nicely drinkable, I liked this.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a pitch black beer with a nicely remaining deep beige head. Strong chocolatey, coffeeish nose which is reminiscent of vanilla, oak and tar. Lucious. Good bitterness. Sourish- this adds to my appreciation of this beer. Surprisingly dry finish which is reminiscent of tar and dark chocolate. Excellent.

355 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone. Rated @ 28.3.2010.
Black colour, large brown head. Classic Porter-style aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Boring taste of weak maltiness and bread. Medium bodied and watery mouthfeel. Average.
First taste is incredibly smoky, but after a few drinks the taste mellows out.

Bottle. Frothy lightbrown fair mostly deminishing head. Black colour. Heavy malty and light hoppy aroma. Roaste and coffee notes and especially lots of nice vanilla. Moderate bitter roasted flavor. Coffee and anilla notes. Long nice finish. Creamy palate. Realy nice beer.
Tap @ Dark Horse for RBSG10 - black chocolate taste, dark and bitter but smooth. tastes like baking chocolate, essentially. Could be sweeter.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 First rating.12 fl oz bottle at Bishops Arms Järntorget, Göteborg. On September 16, 2010Hints of dark red, else black color, dark brown head. Sweet, chocolate, alcohol, fresh scent. Smooth, vinous, hoppy, bitter, griny, chocolate taste. Smooth mouthfeel, long grainy aftertaste. Big bitterenss. Also coffee aftertaste.Very nice, I like it!8/4/8/4/16=4.0RerateBottle thanks to (non-ratebeer) Matt/Nekrobarr! Sampled on December 2, 2012.Black color, big tan head. Sweet, malty scent. Sweet, malty, grainy taste. Medium mouthfeel, roasted aftertaste. High bitterness.7/4/7/4/15=3.7

12oz  botttle.Pours a dark brown-black with khaki head that leaves some lacing here and there. Luscious, multi-layered aroma of chocolate, toffee, molasses, a hint of vanilla, a touch of licorice, and of course roasted grain. Flavor is mostly dry, bitter roast-grain and less balanced than the aroma hints at. Roast grain is followed by coffee, some chocolate, a bit of vanilla, and a hint of dried dark fruit. Some alcohol creeps in as it warms. Full-bodied with a thick, carbonated palate. I wish this beer tasted as good as it smells, but it still tastes pretty good.

12oz Btl. Pours dark with a dark brown head.Great chocolate aroma. Great balanced taste of the coffe and chocolate.Goes down smooth and easy but doesnt lack at all in flavor and body.Im not sure why the donkey looks so sad, I think its great.
Bottle from Archer Liquor. Pours black with a nice brown head and a toasty chocolate aroma. There is a thick chocolate and coffee flavor, slightly carbonated with a dry bitter finish. A good brew.
Pretty nice beer. Chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt in the nose. Taste much of the same. Thin body with a small head. Solid

Bottle.Pours jet balck with a nice beige head.Aroma of choclate,coffe roasted and toasted malts and some hoppy notes.Flavor is sweet malt , coffee,chocolate, herbal hops and  alcohol.Medium to full body,soft carbonation, bitter finish.Very nice porter.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a medium dark brown head. Long lasting and good lacing foam. Aroma is complex: mostly sweet with roasted and toasted notes, dark fruits, coffee and caramel. Taste is mostly sweet again with strong roasty and coffee notes. Almost dry roasty finish. Maybe a bit thin in palate, but overall a splendid and complex brew.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade. Pours the color of thick black coffee with a small, quick fading tan head. Smell was a nice mix of chocolate, coffee and roast. Not an overpowering aroma, but very pleasant. Tasted of roast, coffee, chocolate and some light bits of citrus, surprisingly enough. Finishes a little bitter, but in a good way. Still have yet to be anything but thrilled with any Dark Horse brew.

I was really impressed with this porter!  I had the pleasure of enjoying a pint of it at Canal St. in Reading.  The beer poured basically a black color with a rich and lacing tan head.  The nose was perfectly balanced and very inviting.  I got notes of hops, bread, chocolate and lightly roasted coffee.  The body was extremely smooth, drinkable and wel-balanced.  The flavors are almost perfect, with just the right amount of spicy hops and a big malty profile.  The finish featured some more spiciness, but contained a lot of malts, most notably coffee and chocolate.  Very excellent porter!
Had this one at the UDRBM, 31-07-2010. Black colored brew. Chocolate, coffee in the aroma. Malty flavors, coffee, chocolate, roast, some sweetness, decent bitterness. Sticky.

Pours like black coffee and has a coffee & malt aroma.  It shows indications of being one of those coffee brews.  Apparently there was no actual coffee added to this, however.  Another eccentric DH label, this one with a cartoon horse or mule on it - whats his name?  How about Stephen the Dark Horse?  Shonuff, this has a strong espresso-malt flavor, despite its name, which suggests a schwarzbier.  Fairly sharp and robust, and not sweet.  If you love the coffee porter thing, you will dig this, but Im not part of that club.  A good brew.

On tap at Dark Horse during our trip there during RBSG.  Pours black with a thin beige to tan head.  Soft roast and a faint bit of smoke.  Light smoke and big roastn flavors, with some cocoa on a medium body.  Crisp and clean, nice earthy long roast bitterness and dark malty flavors on the finish.
Bottled. Black pour, nice tan head. Roasty, malty nose. Flavor is roasty, smoky, cocoa powder, coffee, and yeast. Little hop flavor. Nicely bitter finish. Well balanced.

Sampler at Canal Street.  Ale had a light brown head and muddy, black body.  Very good lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts and molasses.  Flavors of roasted nuts, wood, smoke, and honey.  A nice full-bodied, creamy ale with an average hoppiness in the finish.

Now this one was a special beer.  Poured a black color (obviously).  Aroma is of malts, chocolate, smoke, and some slight coffee.  Flavor is of malts, coffee, smoke, nuts, roastiness, chocolate, and licorice.  Nice malty and roasty finish.  Good stuff.

Bottle @ meeting. Solid blackish brown, medium brown creamy head.
Aroma of coffee, mocca, liquorice, earth, peat, chocolate smoky roasted malt. Flavour is very bitter of coffee, peat, earth, chocolate, some smoky spices. Evolves to some sweetness and more coffee.
Very nice.

33cl Bottle at UDRBM. Black colour, brown head. Aroma of hard roasted malts, light smoke, fruits, coffee. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, hard roasted malts, light smoke, good and firm roasted bitter and light hoppy finish with coffee. Medium bodied. Very good.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a brown head. Cocoa and chocolate aroma with notes of dark, ripe fruit. Sweet flavour of cocoa and dark roasted malt. Has an element of spiciness reminding me of Christmas cakes. Ends in a coffee-like bitterness with just a touch of sweetness left on the tongue. Makes the best out of its aromas and flavours and is not complex with variety of flavours but complex in the way the flavours are brought to life. Really a great beer for always having at hand to serve to guests.

Bottle at Dutch RB Meeting. Pitch black pour, thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, butter, coffee and roasted malts. Flavor is bitter and with coffee, some red wine, chocolate and some cream. Creamy texture and average carbonation. Great brew.

Bottle pours almost black with medium brown persistent head.  Aroma chocolate and roast.  Taste burnt malts, caramel, coffee, chocolate.  A bit more burnt taste than I care for.  Palate smooth and fairly thick - others felt this was thin which was not my experience.  Finish long and slightly bitter.  Alcohol well disguised.

Nice porter a bit more burnt than I like otherwise decent.

24-JUL-2010, bottle @home, from Morten.
Black (!) with nice head.
This is not a blak ale, but I can see that it is categorized as a porter which is a better match.
Very fine and roasted aromas with off course the hops to back it up.
Long aftertaste on a slightly thin body that only adds to the drinkability.

Thanks to a nice person at the Bottle share at Sourfest 2010 -- Vintage 2008
Appearance: Pours a coca cola brown with small dense suds.

Aroma: Chocolate, caramel, coconut, wood and cherry.

Taste: Burnt roasted malt, wood, cherry, vanilla, caramel.

Mouthfeel: Thin, chalky with low carbonation.

Overall: A pretty tasty treat, and my first experience with this beer. Id like to compare this to a fresh batch. Everything was money except the mouthfeel.
355 ml bottle. Black with small lasting brown head. Flavour is hard roasted malt, bitter chocolate, bitter coffee and liquorice.

12oz bottle via trade.  Pours just about black with a small tan head that fades to a ring.  Aroma is very chocolatey.  Some roastiness and sweet malt as well.  Flavor is roasty and toasty with milk chocolate and earth.  Tasty stuff.  Smooth and medium-full on the palate with medium-low carbonation.  A really solid beer overall.  Rich and intense for a porter if you want to classify it as such.
The REAL Dark Horse is, of course, Mr. George Harrison, so this beer cannot be considered absolutely authentic, but its still pretty darned good.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty hoppy aroma with hints of chocoalte. Roasted malty chocolate hoppy flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with hoppy hints in the aftertaste.

Has a luscious, smoky aroma with a strong undertone of caramel that demands at least a taste. It pours an opaque dark brown like dark chocolate with a thick, persistent, light tan head. Rich flavor is smoky with a nice bite to it and tones of caramel, molasses and roast coffee. Texture is smooth and pleasing, just a little fizzy.
Bottle thanks to secret Santa. Pours black with tan head. Nose is cream stout, roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is consistent. Lots of cream, coffee grounds, roasted malts and chocolate.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 280610.
Black with beige head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Flavor is smooth sweetness balanced to roasted notes. Nice palate.
Quite nice. Tastes like schwarzbier and a porter had a baby. Serving: Bottle

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2011 Black pour pitch black tan head very nice looking beer decent lacing  .... aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate but kind of light ..... taste of dark chocolate and roasted malts and coffee just a little acidic ..... lingering roasted coffee and chocolate in the finish slight bitter bite in the finish

Bottle at home ... thanks to RCL for this one ... deep black ... thin tan lacing ...  nice soft deep chocolate ... rich treacle toffee nose ... bitter front ... dusty ... roast malts ... dark bitter chocolate ... litttle nut 
... bitter coffee linger ...  more bitter than i like ... but a big winner none the less
Bottle. Almost black, opague. Malt and licorice in the aroma. Full bodied. malty sweet flavor. Licorice hides the milk chocolate notes. Dangerously drinkable and delicious beer.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a lightbrown head. The aroma is malt, roasted, licorice and coffee. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional hops. The palate is roasted and bitter. Overall a really good beer.

Pours dark, with a small tan head.  Aroma is not overpowering.  Taste is smoky, a lot of flavor for a porter.  It leans more to the smoky than the creamy, thicker than it appears.  A very good porter.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Pours Black/brown with a brown head. Aroma of Coffee and roasted malts. Taste is Roasted with sweet malts, coffee, hops, dark chocolate, Nuts (Hazelnuts), smoke and some hops in there too. Very balanced and drinkable!
Draft @ Dark Horse Brewery. Black colour, brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and hops. Flavour is roasted malts, bitter coffee, chocolate, and hops. Balanced.

12oz bottle. This is a big, bold porter. Lots of chocolate, coffee, roast, and some dark fruits on the nose. Medium body and round in the mouth; roasty with very nice dark fruit middle and a nice bitter finish. Surprised to see the ABV on this.

12oz traded bottle. Pours dark black with a tall brown head. Reminds me of Cola. Nice aroma that had some sweet, sour, and malty notes...interesting. The flavour is where the coffee and bittersweet baking chocolate appeared for me. Surprisingly light body made it easy to drink. Well done.

Bottle. Black with tan head that thins. Aroma is big roasted chocolate, light burnt coffee, notes of mango berry fruit. Taste is also roasted chocolate going big bitter finish of coffee. Medium bodied, not too heavy. Long roasted bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle from my brother. Nice light viscous pour. The beer carries a nice fluffy light brown head. Also, the beer has a lovely black and opaque appearance. Lovely aroma of sweet chocolate. Light smore and graham cracker aroma as well. There is a subtle roast flavor, but I would prefer my porters to only have a subtle roast aroma/flavor because the roast can, at times, be a bit caustic. Hm...Im getting a subtle sweet syrup aroma as well. This beer has an awesome nuanced aroma. Wow, nice smooth texture. Light roast at first, but then the hops and roast flavor mix together providing an amazing bitterness that just drives my taste buds insane. Sweet chocolate is there, but that bitterness sets this port apart from the rest. This one carries a nice oily and creamy texture that makes this a very smooth beer. Deep roast flavor is awesome. This is a very unique and nice porter. Hard to say that this one doesnt stand out from all of the other porters that Ive ever had. Thanks bro, this ones for you.

Very dark in color with a brownish head. Aroma is of very roasty malt. Very deep flavors of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and nuts. Smooth lingering finish. Not as thin as some porters, this one has a lot of body to it. Nice.

bottle courtesy of jcb, nice extra! pours a thick brown with a medium tan head. aroma is really nice, tons of chocolate, smoke, and a stange but pleasant candy hint to it. nice full body, not too, heavy, not watery. the taste is char, molasses, smoke, peats, nice, but not overpowering. very well rounded and full porter.

Black with quickly dissipating head. Really nice aroma of spice coffee and fruit. Flavor is like a chocolate covered blueberry dipped in coffee. Yup. That about sums it up. Thanks to grownfool for the trade!

Draft @ Coles, Buffalo NY> Dark black pour. Nice roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate & light coffee. Taste is extremely smooth & blanced. Roasted malts, hibts of choclate & coffee. Solid porter . Nice mouthfeel.

Does this brewery do a bad beer????? I dont think so..... jet black almost in its pour, nose is bitter black malts, inky and anise. mouth feel is nice not to heavy not too light. flavor is an amazing well balanced almost imperial porter... the booze is there but well hidden, had a few of these

Pours black into an english pint. Mocha head with excellent retention leaves slight spots as it recedes to coat surface. Roasted chocolate and espresso aromas. Thick with upfront sweet espresso and chocolate syrup turning to burnt coffee rinds and bitter smoked chocolate in the lasting finish.

On tap at Coles. Appearance: pitch black, medium brown head. Aroma: lightly roasty with a little milk and malt. Flavour: deliciously burnt malt, vanilla, a good hint of alcohol, smokey, long bitter
yet smokey finish. Delicious.

Served on tap on 5-10-10 at Kraftwork.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a two finger head with decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting cap and ring. Minimal spots of lacing.

Sweet roasted malt aroma with lots of burnt toast, chocolate malt, molasses, brown sugar and espresso/coffee bean. Possibly some licorice. Earthy hops provide a nice balance of bitterness to the roasted and sweet notes.

Lighter bodied than expected with a lot of dark roasted malts up front with hints of chocolate, burnt toast, coffee and oatmeal. Decently balanced by a sweet chocolate and molasses/honey flavor and some nice bitter, dry hops. Very dry finish. Complex but thinner than I expected or would have liked. Well balanced and drinkable.

12oz bottle. Pours dark black with a creamy head and decent lacing. Wiithout looking too closely to the label I assumed this was going to be one of those dark colored lagers that look good but dont quite cut it. Luckily it became immediately apparent that this was a solid porter and a good one at that. Thick oily mouth feel with delicious tastes of chocolate and coffee. Good stuff.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by FrumptyDumpty ]. Clear dark black color with a average, frothy to creamy, good to excellent lacing, fully lasting, light brown to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, coffee. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate, dark roasted malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery carbonation is soft. [20100422]

Bottle from a trade with SuzyGreenberg. Pours black with minimal brown head. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. Burnt malt flavor with some chocolate and a hint of coffee. Slightly ashy finish. Full body with minimal carbonation. Thanks Ben.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours black with red edges. Big, staying, creamy, beige head. Lovely. Aroma has some relative sweetness, milky chocolate, mild roasted, a hint of blackberries. Low carbonation, lovely creamy and dryish mouthfeel. Flavour is quite dry, some grainy coffee grind, dark chocolate, a tad milky. Medium roasted and very dry finish, just bordering a slight bit on a metallic note.

Black big tan head great retention... dark fruits chocolate coffee aroma roasty... medicinal up front, somewhat creamy roasty, not as tasty as the aroma, some fruits... medium to medium full bodied.... decent, not as bold as I expected...

pitch dark brown, smooth quite small light brown head.
fruity and caramelly, toffee, chocolaty aroma. too fruity and flowery for me. too much hops?
flavor is much better. roasted stuff, bitterness, nutty bitterness, faint charchoal, unfortunately some banana like fruitiness too. not sure if it is slighlty infected but the banana fruitiness is a bit strange. apart from that a hard roasted experience.
after the beer has been staying open for an hour the taste improved a bit.
Black with a lasting tan head. Vineous roasted and dried fruit aroma. Sweet and rasted flavour

Fløska. Nice black colour, medium light brownish head, ok lacing. Aroma of roasty malt with coffee and chocolate, soft. Good mouthfeel. Flavour of roasty malt, coffee chocolate and mild pleasant bitterness. SDoft roasty malty and chocolate finish. Nice.
scura buona schiuma piuttosto persistente naso intenso cioccolalto caffe liquirizia cosi anche in bocca intese tostature buon amaro discreta luppolatura
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, complex, chocolate, coffee and tobaco. Flavour is roasted malt, tobaco, chocolate and cold coffee.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, April 2010. Pours pitch black with a small creamy beige head and lacings. Nose & flavor is vinous and complex. Cold coffee, roast, ashy and chocolate. Very dry and smooth. Hard roasted malt. Nice

Draught.  I actually thought this was a black beer at first and was surprised at the chocolate content, but now that I see its a porter it makes more sense. Anyway, very chocolatey, goes well with certain foods.  Well done.

This is a black beer with a foamy light brown head.  Dark brown sugar sweetness in the nose with some roasted malt notes.  Lots of roasted grains and bitter tea with some sweetness.  Full flavored beer without being too heavy.

$10 / sixer - - When I purchased this, I thought it was going to be a black lager; nope, it is a porter.  It taste like a porter, a really dry, roasted porter.  Maybe slightly dry on the finish, but I really like this.  Dark Horse is becoming one of my favorite and reliable breweries.

Black with a large beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, dark chocolate, espresso and hoppy notes. Sweet flavour with burned malt, dark chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Finished dry with plenty of hops. Finished dry.

Flaske: Flot sort øl med et lille gennemskin. Fint lysebrunt skumhoved. Duften er sødlig maltet, med en del brændthed i sig. Smagen er sø porter med en ordentlig gang tørhumling inden bagved. Ikke så god som New world porter fra avery men deroppe af. Fin øl.

Had a few times, most recently on Tap at Dmacs. Pours out black with a moderate tan head. Nice aroma of roast, chocolate and some coffee. Taste is smooth, with a nice silky mouthfeel, full flavored notes of chocolate, coffee, roast, and slight bitterness. Overall a top notch porter.

Bottle at home. Pours black with a small beige head. Smells of roasted malts. Dry with a low sweetness. Lots of aroams of hard roasted malts. Hints of dark chocolate. Medium bodied. Soft carbonation. Dry finish with more roasted malts. Kinda unballanced?

Bottle kindly shared by the man on the top - plovmand. 
Pours pitch black with a light brown head. 
Aroma is roasted malt, tar, coffee and a little chocolate. 
Flavour is loads of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.

Bottle. Pitch black with a creamy tan head. Nice roasted aroma with a good sweet caramel kick. Some coffee and light chocolate. The flavour is heavy roasty with rich coffee and tar. Some lighter chocolate notes. Full bodied. It ends up super roasty.

Pours very dark, opaque black body with a light brown head that leaves sheets of thick tan lacing. Light toasty aroma of chocolate and coffee, with a bit of ranch dressing. Dense and powerful flavor with lots of roast, chocolate, coffee, tobacco, and smoke. Long bitter finish. Massive body with light carbonation. The aroma doesnt do this justice. Very good porter.

Bottled at OHaras, Tampere. Black with rusty head. Roasty aroma with coffee and perfumed hops. The flavor is smoothly roasty and burned with coffee, charcoal, leather and salty licorice. Smooth slightly oily palate. Tasty and drinkable.

Bottled at Pikkulintu. Nose hints of chocolate and blue cheese. Thin head. Dark reddish black colour. Coffeyish espressolike taste. Quite dry taste. Mild hoppiness. Slightly oily. Quite bitter finish. Quite nice beer.
Thin black pour with a tan head.  Roasty aroma.  Slightly watery bitter roast flavor.  Lots of coffee grounds.  Slight fruity sourness.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours pitch black with a medium duration dark brown head. Aroma is distinct hard/dark roasted malt, burned breadish and dark and rich chocolate. Dark roasted to burned malt flavour, solid bitter chocolate and slight tarish. Acidic hard roasted malt flavoured. Bitter, dry and acidic finish. Too hard roasted for my liking.

(Bottle at Maltainen Riekko) Poured black with medium sized and brown head. Aroma contained ash, sourness and liquorice. Palate was medium bodied and stinging with plenty of carbonation. Flavours were roastedness, liquorice, burntness, hops, ash and bitterness. Aftertaste was ashy and bitter.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Pitch black - brown edges.  Chocolate, coffee, sweetness, raisins, smooth body, grassy, medium hoppy. Nice.
Bottle.Pitch black colour with beige head.Aroma of salty licorice and coffee nice well balanced with note of dark chocolate and malt,hint of vanilla and cream.
Dark brown pour with deep tan head and lace. Aroma of abv, toasted malt, chocolate. Dark chocolate, abv flavor with a nice malt bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation. a very nice beer.

Bottle. Low but lasting creamy light brown head. Pitch black body. Roasted barley malt coffee choccolate cream aroma. Relatively bitter and highly carbonated coffee choccolate flavor with hints of the alcohol. Long roasted bitter aftertaste.
Bottle: pours dark black with a thin tan head, aroma of coffee and roasted malts, taste is malty, some chocolate, coffee, mild bitterness, medium bodied

Now this brewery is represented with several different bottles in Ølbutikken - Heres the first one that hit my glass. Pitch black pour with lots of black in - The head is very brown and frothy - this is truely a black beer but not a Scwartz Bier as known from Germany -The nose is interesting and temping - like an aphrodisium. Therefore I directly passed this sweet thing to my gf to hear her words on the aroma. ...she came up with brown sugar, desert wine like Suternes. Iagree on that but also gets the roasted malts, some coffee and dark chocolate and a slight hint of smoke. The taste is bitter and roasted. Hoppy and burned notes dominates the smooth and medium thick palate. The finish is burning a bit but still dominated of a long lasting bitterness. This beer could be an excellent choice to serve to some different strong and sweet cheeces. By the way - whats up with the sad donkey on the lable?

Pours black as ebony with a nice dark tan head. The aroma is very warm and earthy, with the subtleties of lemongrass and pine. Nicely thick and malty, but not too much--elegance in simplicity. Finishes bitter and hoppy, which is a little odd for the style, but a nice change. It also balances out the sweetness well, making a very good overall beer.
Bottle. Black color, medium brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolat, some hop, coffee. Quite bitter coffee taste, bit malt, quite bitter. Bitter finish.

bombaaaa!!! colore nero piuttosto opaco schiuma sottile marrone... al naso caffè tostato legno caramello arrostito..al palato è morbida avvolgente medio corpo finale amaro leggero... ottimo equilibrio

(Bottled) Almost black with a small, firm, quite quickly fading, beige and lacy head. Mild, roasted-earthy-sourish-malty aroma with some coffee and a touch of licorice. Flavor is sourish and roasted-malty with some licorice and vegetables. Medium to full body, lowish carbonation. Slightly unclean and sour, but reasonably enjoyable porter in the Baltic style. 5-5-5-6

Schiuma bruna molto persistente..un profumo molto elegante con marcate note di cioccolato e caffè....percettibile lamaro tostato e un piccolo ma interessante luppolo...Molto secca,tostata e marcate note di cioccolato..note di malto bruciato e ben persistente..buona buona birra....

Very dark pour generates a black, thick liquid with a small dark brown ring of foam. Aroma of salty liqourice, molasses, soy sauce and roasted malt with some caramell and vanilla. Flavour is similar with sharp, almost harsh roasted malts that comes across as some what restrained. Mouthfeel is medium full with rather sharp carbonation.

Pours pitch black with a thin amount of tan head.  Nice aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Very smooth taste, with a light almost velvety mouthfeel that ends with a nice smooth chocolate taste.  Really tasty, really smooth, almost no taste of the alcohol.

Not a hint of light escapes this brew.  Black with a very thin tan head.  Coffee, bitter chocolate, and dark fruits dominate the aroma.  Quite inviting.  Medium, creamy mouthfeel with some decent carbonation.  Like the aroma, the flavor is dominated by bitter chocolate and dark fruits.  It finishes with a nice coffee punch.  Pretty good beer.

Pours black with a thin tan head.  Roasted malt and molasses aroma.  Dark Chocolate, Smoke, and coffee flavors mixed with a hopped induced freshness uncharacteristic of a typical porter.  Smooth, yet slightly bitter finish.  As good as this bottle was, it simply cant compare to getting it fresh on tap at the brewery.

#2000! Bottle from Bierkoning. Beautiful dark brown body with tan head. Strong porter nose of molasses, chocolate and coffee. Complex taste of malts, molasses, dark fruits and some chocolate. Very creamy and lucious. Gets spicier towards the finish. (Dont they all?)
Pours black like motor oil with a small brown head. The aromas are of roasted and chocolate malt. It has a full-bodied palate that is dry, bitter, and long lasting. This is a good sipper. Enjoyable.

Bottle (thanks to guyinchicago for the trade)...  Poured black with a light brown head.  Aroma of malts, cocoa and was metallic.  Thick palate, dry and well carbonated.  A well smoked and roasted beer with an overall metallic character.  Malty, popcorn-like grains, cracker and biscuity.  Solid bitterness and tanginess to the brew and finished very clean.

A decent porter but nothing special. Aroma was average. Coffee with roasted malt. Pour was a deep dark black with a tan film for a head. Taste was thin and watery. Not much in the front with a bitter coffee aftertaste. Medium carbonation. There really was not much flavor in this beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Loads of chocolate in the aroma with sweet coffee and black currant. Black colour, brown head, good lace. Light sweet, malty, coffee, bitter roasted finish, medium body. Flavourful, balanced, easy going.

Tasted blind next to Founders Porter. 
A darn fine porter, but next to the Founders it pales a little bit. The mouthfeel on the Founders is better, and a little roastier-oxidized. 
Nonetheless, totally deserving of its excellent reviews.
DecemBeer. Sample from a bottle shared by decaturstevo.  Dark brown, tan head.  Lovely roasty, chocolate aroma.  Taste is chocolate, roast, sweet.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2012 12 oz. bottle from City-Wide in South Bend- thanks shawnm213 for getting it for me.  Pours such a dark brown motor oil-like color, near black, with a small brown head that leaves a ring along the edge.  Aroma of chocolate, hazelnut, roast, hops, coffee, peat, and dark fruits.  Flavor is dark chocolate, coffee, roast, nuts, dark fruits, hops, burnt toast, brown sugar, and earthy notes.  Medium bodied, with an oily, syrupy mouthfeel and roasty finish.  Lingering roast aftertaste.  Great porter. Re-Rate: 8/28/12. This isnt as good as I remember. Good porter, but so dry. Maybe I just got a great bottle before and a weaker one this time. Just not what I thought it was.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2015 2/27/15: bottle from Kroger in Grandview. Blackish pour, khaki head. Aroma of milky bitter chocolate. Tastes are cocoa, chocolate, vanilla, light smoke. This is really well made, but not to my tastes.  12/17/09:  12oz bottle.  Black pour with a thin tan head that leaves a ring.  Nice roasted malt, chocolate and coffee aroma.  Flavors are the same with hints of dark fruit and molasses.  Smooth and sharp bitter finish - both dry and astringent.

Pours black as night, with virtually no head.  Roasty chocolate and coffee teases the nostrils and tongue, with a hop kick and smooth finish.  Not as creamy as I expected, but overall it improves as it warms.

Black oily pour with a thin tan head.  Bitter roast and chocolate nose.  Loads of roast as well.  Mouthfeel is viscous and oily.  Flavor is bitter Roast all the way through.  chocolate malt, and deep earthy bitterness emanate off of this.  Rich and very nice
pretty good porter. aq little on the sweet side as opposed to roasty, but not too sweet. solid in my opinion, but nothing too special here.

12 oz bottle. Poured opeque black in color with a small tan head that left little lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, toffee, coffee.  Tastes of roasted coffee, cream, oats, chocolate, fairly sweet.  Nice lingering sweet chocolate, and coffee in the finish.  Quite nice.

Deep brown pour with moderate mocha head, strong aroma of toasted malt laced with chocolate, rich mouthfeel, smooth and chocolatry with some toasty flavors up front that comes roaring in the finish as roasted bitterness.
Black pour with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate and dark fruit. Smooth with a slight alcohol and bitter chocolate finish.

12 oz bottle into a tulip.  Pours dark brown/black with a thin brown coffee-colored head that dissipated fully.  Aroma is a wonderful mix of dark fruit (plums/dates), sweet malt, roast coffee, molasses, and bitter dark chocolate.  Tastes of coffee, bitter hops, dark chocolate, and a touch of sweetness.  Finishes quite dry.  Thin, somewhat watery mouthfeel, but smooth with very subtle carbonation.  Delicious, and the aroma really makes this one a winner.
Pours black. Smells of heavy roasted malts, chocolate and caramel. Taste is full bodied and a little ashy with notes of chocolate, coffee and a hops bitter to finish. Nice balance.
Dark with an off white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, some creamy coffee. Flavor is sweet, malty, roasted coffee and roasted malts. Slightly bitter to balance it out. Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2014 Pours thick, curtain of black.  The beer itself actually sticks to the side of the glass like oil.  Beautiful orange tan head.  Heavy lacing.  Smells of roasted barley, molasses, brown sugar, and toffee.  Roasted malts exploding on the taste buds.  Great mouthfeel. Dry and slightly sour.  Medium low hoppiness.  Creamy, smooth and delicious.
Pours black creamy dark tan / brown head.  Aroma is roasty, burned coffee, sweet malt.  The taste is astonishingly wonderful!  Chocolate bitter sweet joy.
Tap at Eulogy. Poured dark black. This has the flavor of a stout and the body of a porter. Nice mouthful and nicely carbonated. Great coffee flavor and awesome. Bitter finish.

Bottle from West Lakeview. Pours black/brown with a creamy dark head. Nose is roasty and floral, cocoa as well. On taste, clean bitterness with a nice acrid note that pulls it together. Slightly sweet and chocolatey. Very nice.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured black with a thick brown head. Flavor was full of roasted malts with undertones of roasted coffee. Flavor begins with a mocha kick, but dark grain flavors take over giving a roasted malt flavor.

Courtesy of nbutler11, thanks Nick. Its pitch black with a dark brown, creamy head and the aroma has notes of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, cocoa and licorice  its full and alluring. The flavor is sweet with notes of chocolate, coffee, light dark fruits, licorice and the overall impression is harmonic, nice, full and intense...
Excellent beer. A big brown head with lots of chocolate in the nose. The flavor is very smooth and rich. A dry chocolate finish. Well done.
Smell of chocolate and booze with a hint of vanilla.  Smell gives the impression of light body.........smoked, roasted coffee malty nutty flavor.  Good stuff!

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm, 2 Oct 2009) Black colour with frothy, brown head. Malty, roasted nose with dark chocolate, strong black coffee and liquorice. Malty, roasted taste with notes of black coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruit, liquorice and a balanced coffee bitterness in the finish. Slightly above medium body, with some sweetness. Very nice porter.

Pours black with a dark tan head. Strong coffee aroma backed by chocolate. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Flavor is primarily coffee with burnt malt. Definitely bitter. Finishes smooth and burnt and bitter. Very nice ale.

I worship the ground that Dark Horse Brewers walk on.  If I ever turn into a boozehound, they are partly responsible.  It really doesnt get any better than this.  The Special Black Bier is really a stout, though not a super strong one--it drinks very easy.  Not very complex--typical of most stouts--but a nice body.  Dark Horse Brewerys Uno Oatmeal Stout is also delish--recommended if you like this one.  Last, their IPA is unusual and very good too.

Bottle.  Duh -- its black.  Almost no head, surprisingly.  The aroma is full-on chocolate syrup.  It drinks with a big-time richness, with bitter dark chocolate as the primary component, a little bit of woodiness finishing it off.  Tasty beer.  (#3677, 9/19/2009)

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in an opaque black appearance topped with a small beige head. Rich but a bit simplistic aroma of black chocolate with minty and grassy hops. Nearly full-bodied with strong notes of chcoalte sauce, cocoa powder, cookies and mint. Long full medium-bitter aftertaste of dark chocolate, brown sugar, crackers, grass, mint, mild black pepper and mild alcohol. Flavorful but a tad too sticky and rough.

Bruegala 2009 sampling - Pours a pitch black with a large, light brown head that leaves some fair amount of lacing on the glass. Aroma has an average grainy, burnt note with notes of coffee and toasted malt. Hops provides a  light grassy note with some dark fruit - raisin, prune notes. Flavor is a very strong acidic coffee note with a light dryness to it and lots of burnt malt character and bitter bakers chocolate/dark chocolate flavor. Moderate body and a thin texture with a modest amount of carbonation. Overall I think the coffee character of this brew really detracted from the overall enjoyability of the brew.

BPW #23
Served on tap at Dark Horse Brewing Company. Appearance is a deep black with a nice roasted brown head. Aromas are heavy roasted malt with a nice dose of roasted coffee bean. Flavors follow suite but the tongue picks up more of a chard flavor. The malt profile is very pleasant. Palate is very dry and moderately full. A real nice beer that I am glad to of tried fresh on tap.

Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #23 of 90. Tap at D.H. thanks Dan. Pours black with brown edges and thin brown head. Good amount of dark malts and coffee on the nose. Tasty roasted malts, coffee and a mild hop flavor round this one out nicely.

This beer pours a deep black, opaque with a nice dark mocha head. The aroma is mostly roast with a touch of malt fruitiness. Theres just something missing for me. The flavor has a touch of chocolate but again is mostly a mild roasted maltiness. There are some hops in there providing an interesting bitterness. Its a clean stout that sticks to roastiness for its character. I wish there was a bit more of this character, but Im just being picky. The mouthfeel is smooth. Drinkability is good.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malts, slight burnt malts, chocolate, cream, light piney hops, and a hint of bitter coffee.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, slightly rocky, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Lightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malts, slight burnt malts, cream, light chocolate, light bitter coffee, slight hops, and a hint of wood.  Medium body.  Slick, creamy texture is a tad thin.  Soft carbonation.  Roasted malts, light cream, light chocolate, and slight vanilla finish is boring.

Pours jet black with a dark tan head.  Nose is roast, some sweet coffee, bitterness, and licorice.  Flavor is earth, burnt malt, some band-aid, and some ash and smoke.  Nice mouthfeel gives way to lingering ashy smoke.  Yellow lace abounds.  Medium to full bodied beer.
Very dark very awesome liquid with a nice tight tan foam.  very coffee roasty aroma.  good bold coffee with a hint of chocolate flavor.  Silky body and dry on the back end.  very very nice.

Eagan, Mn. - Cellars Wine and Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Dark black pour with a quickly fading khaki colored head. Strong coffee and chocolate aroma. Good bold, earthy flavor with lots of black dirt, coffee and chocolate, hints of licorice. Nice, chalky mouthfeel with a dry finish. Excellent porter.
Dark brown color with a small brown head. Aroma of roasted and chocolate malts. Flavor of bitter dark chocolate with a coffee finish. Good.
Very dark, strong dark tan creamy dense head.  Strongly burnt grain aroma with a little twinge of sour green apple.  Medium bodied, more burnt grain with some toasted almond, dry finish.

I had this on tap at MBGSF 09.  I  guess there was something wrong with the tapper, so I didnt have to give up a token up for it.  It definitely was black, with a huge brown bubbly head (probably from the bad tap).  It had a really light aroma, a tiny bit of roasted coffee but minimal at that.  Very light flavor, watery mouth feel and no prominent flavors.  It was very mild.
bottle, very dark brown color with minimal foam, aroma light roasted coffee, flavor has a very strong bittersweet, baking chocolate side, hoppy with a sharp finish

This one poured a dark dark brown color with a normal sized light tan head. Aroma was very burnt and roasted. Flavor was also very roasted, not as much silkiness and chocolate as i would have hoped from this porter, but nonetheless a good beer.
poured out of bottle into glass. rich, chocolate-coffee taste. Very good if you like dark beers.

Pours dark black with a small brown head that quickly fades.  Aroma of roasted malt and some citrus.  Starts off with flavors of vanilla, malts and chocolate and finishes off with burnt coffee and hops.  Fairly thin body  Not bad.  Interesting beer.

The label doesnt say porter, it doesnt say anything.  I was hoping I was buying a strong ale.  So when I realized I had a porter on my hands I was instantly dissapointed since Im not a porter/stout fan.  I tried a couple of sips.  Super rich, thick powerfulbodied.  Dark horse might want to put the make on the label next time.

Holy crap this is some nice porter. Pours a deep black with a smallish dark tan head that eventually fades to a long lasting espresso swirl style head. The aroma is at first very strong with vanilla some roasty notes almost a peaty character finished with a strong hazelnut aroma. The flavor is a little vanilla at first that fades away right quick then it is very dry and bitter, strongly roasty with some great coffee tones, plenty of molasses and a nice little nuttiness and raisin in the background. Complex and awesome.

Not sure what this beer wants to be, perhaps it doesnt want to be anything except for a tasty dark ale.  Opaque brown body, very dark color.  Thin brown head and spotty lacing.  Aroma of burnt pan leavings, roasted malt, coffee and more roasted malt.  Thick with an upfront bitterness followed by a burnt kick.  Finishes full.  Heavily roasted flavor with an English malt influence.  Some dark berries and lots of bitter hops.  A lingering after taste of coffee and nuts.

12 oz bottle courtesy of SamGamgee.  Poured a dark, brown/black wiht a minimal tan head.  Nose of chocolate and coffee.The taste was of  roasted malts and bittersweet chocolate.  did not taste too heavy and had a nice dry finish.

12oz bottle.   Almost black color with a beige head.   Milk chocolate aroma with emphasis on the milk part; creamy, burnt, and a bit smokey.   Dry and roasty in the finish with some chocolate sweetness to start, and a firm hop bitterness.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   You might guess that this was lower in abv by how it drinks.

Bottle courtesy SamGamgee. Pours blackish with brown highlights and a dark tan head. Aroma is straightforward milk and dark chocolates, with maybe a lactose note. Super roasty flavor with black, roasted, burnt barley notes and an even bitterness. Dry, maybe a bit astringent. Still pretty good.
Bottle, thanks Shawn. Pours black, with a brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, malt, and some hops. Flavor is chocolate, hops, coffee, and dark fruit.

12 oz bottle

Thanks for someone for sending this as a bonus.  Now that it is available locally I may have to pick up a sixer in the future.  While it is not a spectacular porter it is well enough done to merit the roughly $10 price point for six bottles.  I hope more Dark Horse makes it way to Ohio soon.

Aroma / Appearance - The tan thin head and black fluid body contain a mix of smoky chocolate, rich coffee, and maltiness.   It smells much like you would expect a porter to smell, especially one from a brewery who knows what they are doing.

Flavor / Palate - Smoke, bittersweet chocolate, and an intense roasty aspect form the base of a solid experience.  Without being over the top in coffee grounds it gives a smooth espresso-like flavor to the finish.  At 7.5% ABV it is very drinkable and worth investigating further.

Black beer with a frothy dark tan head, very nice lacing.  Sweet malt aroma like chocolate covered dark fruits, powerful but not overly so.  Aroma is more powerful than the flavor but flavor is much the same.  Bit of a sour bitter finish.  Coffee in the finish.  Nice and easy to drink.

pours a deep brown with a tan head.  roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, toast, coffee, nuts, liquorice.  very smooth and drinkable.  slightly sticky and creamy mouthfeel.  pretty happy with this one.

Nice coffee/roasted aroma to start with, just hints of chocolate.  Pours an opaque black, with a dusting of light tan head.  The flavor of the beer comes across with bitter coffee and chocolate notes.  Nice full mouthfeel, and very drinkable.  A good solid beer, and yet another reason Im happy that Dark Horse has started distributing to Cleveland.

Poured a beautiful silky black with rather modest head. The head is dark-brown, like the "crema" on the espresso. Has an oily look and dissipates within a minute to a thin film. Chocolate notes on the palate. Rather light formation of Belgian lace. Nice lingering. Medium body. Not as dense as the color and pour suggested. Subdued roasted notes. Hints of coffee. Some bitter hops. I like it, but am not overly impressed. I expected more ale yeast character. While I will not seek it out, it is better than a great many beers.

Pours a deep black, motor oil like in color and texture with a medium brown head. Aroma is of dark chocolate, some coffee, earthiness, and some hints of nuts. Flavor is similar, chocolate, coffee, nuts, malts, toffee, some sweet roastiness, and a slightly bitter finish. Quite good overall.
Porterish. Nice to look at. Thick mouthfeel, quite creamy. Moderately bitter finish.  Kind of bland.

Pours motor oil black with thin burgundy rings when held to light. The 2 finger creamy tan head has decent retention and fades to a nice thick skim and ring after a while. Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted almonds, lots of roast, herbal hops, a little char, burnt sugar, coffee, and dry forest earthiness. Flavor is dark roast coffee, rich dark chocolate, loads of roast, an odd nip of blackberry, plums, a hint of fresh cut grass, a little earthy smoke. Toffee, roasted nuts, lighter roast malt, caramel and bitter hops to finish. Palate is medium thickness with a lightly syrupy feel and a slightly too sharp level of carbonation. Finish seems to coat the tongue, feels a little oily.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 12 oz. bottle (2009) in a shaker; pours a pitch black w/ a large cinnamon head that rapidly diminishes into nothingness, lending this beer an almost Cola-like appearance; aroma hits you with the chocolate straight up, followed by coffee, hazelnut and sweet roastiness- pretty standard, smokey porter flavors, very nicely defined in this case; flavor is more chocolate, w/ the coffee bitterness a lot more evident than in the nose- this takes over and leads into a long, chicory bitter finish; thin-medium bodied. Quite a tasty brew, but the finish is a little heavy on the coffee. Probably on par with the Edmund Fitzgerald, but nowhere as smooth as the Founders Porter.

2008 btl.  Pours inky black with gorgeous mocha head.  Very roasty, bitter, loads of coffee.   Hints of Bourbon.  Palate is lacking a bit, not much complexity or mouth feel.  Lingering alcohol presence.   Tasty, but not great.

Bottle thanks to northernbrews!Black with a decent beige head, qoes quickly to a ring with little lacing. Nose is burnt sugar, malt, licorice. More licorice, salt, sugar, and tar in the flavor. Very dry, bitter, moderate bitter with a strong finish. Pretty good, but I dont find it very enjoyable.

Received in a trade. I dont recall from whom, but again...thank you. The style here in BP says a schwarzbier. No way in hell is this a schwarzbier. Too sweet, too much body..too much everything to be a lager. But its tasty I know that much. The beer pours out a deep black color with a rich, creamy 1/2" tan head. Swirling my glass, the beer has some really nice legs to boot. The aroma is very roasty, with lots of dark chocolate, anise and vanilla. Flavor had almost too much "ash" flavor of black patent malt, but rides the edge of just enough and too much. Black patent can be overused but someone restrained themselves enough not to go completely overboard. Coffee and chocolate round out the flavor with some molassess and subtle boozy vanilla hints creep up. But a very enjoyable beer.

My rating is probably not at all reliable.  I dont like this sort of bier and expected more of a Shwarzbier style.  This is so dark and burnt.  But I nonetheless sense that it is probably good for its style.  It seems to be well formed and made.

very soft nose. plenty of coffee and chocolate in flavor but a nice dose of hops set this apart from the standard fare. hard to believe this is substantial in terms of ABV as it is....comes across as a 5%er.
Really nice porter.  Smooth, with more fruitiness than you usually get from a porter like this.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 Bottle.  Saw this brewery for the first time at my local beer store and picked up a few.  This is my first Dark Horse beer.  I have to say Im surprised.  Its a black color beer with a thin dark brown head.  Aroma is strong, smells of roasted malt and alcohol.  Sweet initial flavor with a dry bitter end.  Has hints of coffee and chocolate that compliment each other well.
Nice black pour with a brown head. Great aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Tastes great. Flavor of malt, chocolate and some sweetness. Left a great taste in the mouth. Worthy of trying again.

Bottle from Breeze-Thru.  Pours pitch black and thick.   It actually made a glugging noise that reminded me of a quart of oil pouring out.  Aroma has quite a bit of smokiness, chocolate, and coffee.  Starts fairly sweet and chocolately up front.  The smoked malt comes forward as well.  Finishes with quite a bit of bitter expresso flavor and a tiny bit of alcohol.  It has a nice smooth and fairly thick mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  This is a very good porter and Ill definitely drink again.

12oz bottle, served in an English pint glass.  A slick, oily black pour with no head and miniamal oily legs.  Typical of most of the Dark Horse dark beers Ive had out of the bottle.  The aroma consisted of heavy bittersweet chocolate, molasses, and some ripened dark fruits.  The flavor had heavy roasted notes, chocolate, burnt caramel, molasses, and dark fruit.  The mouthfeel was slippery and medium to full-bodied.  Minimal carbonation.  Rich and very roasty for a porter.  Decent, but I prefer DHs stout series over this.

On tap @ Dark Horse.  I had this beer after the Fore Smoked Stout and I liked this one much better.  Pours black with a brown head.  Roasted chocolate malt with some dark fruit.  A touch of coffee and a little bit of bitterness.  I enjoyed it.

Black pour with a 2 finger, lasting tan head.  Cocoa aroma with a hint of brown sugar, and some subtle spicy hops.  The flavor is much more muted than the aroma.  Theres some soft chocolate flavor and a little bitter roastiness on the finish with just a bit of hop bitterness.  Creamy, medium body.

12oz bottle pours extremely dark with a dark brown, soapy head.  Aroma shows intense roastiness, certainly roastier than most stouts let alone porters.  Waves of dark chocolate and toasted wheat bread appear over just the tiniest amount of fruitiness, perhaps dark berries.  Some char and burnt aromas are also noted.  Flavor is intensely roasty with notes of bitter, dark chocolate.  Quite intense flavor really.  The intensity might reach over to astringency, honestly, as the burnt toast flavor affects drinkability.  Bitterness is a little over the top as well.

2009 Bottle - Thanks dmschefke! - Pours almost a syrupy black with a medium brown head...aroma is cocoa malt, dark fruit and a bit of roast...flavour coats the mouth, charred wood and toasted grain...highly astringent bitterness throughout that lingers considerably...the coffee malt becomes more apparent after you aclimate to the bitterness... quite nice!

Porter? Hah, no way. Big black pour with a choco moose head. Pours like an imp stout, smells like a good imp stout. Tasted is roasted, burned and forward. Like any other impy stout. Must be in the wrong style category. Gunk on bottom of bottle, yum. Big impression with a bitter finish. wew
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12oz bottle.  Black pour with a medium light brown head.  Malty and chocolatey aroma with coffee, some dark fruit and a touch of alcohol.  Coffee flavor with chocolate and a hoppy finish.  Very good beer, but slightly too much hops.  Gonna sit on one for a while and see how she does.

Bottle.  Pours with a browner head and more inky blackness than any porter I can recall.  Tons of roast and coffee in the aroma, but some anise as well. Flavor is delightfully bitter chocolate and coffee, very dry with a lingering spicy bitterness.  Almost loamy.  Medium body, low carb and a sticky end.  Another fantastic MI porter, this one poured to celebrate MSUs victory against Louisville in the NCAA tourney.
Black color with a thin tan head. Light coffee aroma. Flavor of dark chocolate with a dry finish.

Pours a nice black with medium brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt evident.  Taste of chocolate, coffee, and black liquorice.  Very dry mouthfeel with an aftertaste of a bitter hops.  Altogether a very nice dry porter.

Pours very dark near black, medium mocha head. Dry "chalky" aroma, and something almost spicy, as of cardamom(?!). Quite dry roasty flavor, and this cardamom impression comes through in the finish. Very unusual aftertaste, almost hoppy bitterness, almost rubber, and spice. This is a quality dry porter, even though my preference is for the sweeter variety.
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate. Some coffee and chocolate. Little bit of hops. Good stuff.
Bottle. Pours black with thin dark brown head. Aroma is chocolatey and malty with notes of coffee. Flavor is dark and slightly bitter with coffee and chocolate notes.
Pours a dark brown color with a nice tan head.  Aroma is mostly chocolate with some coffee, roasted malts, and molasses.  Flavor is the same with a little bitterness on the finish.
Pour was a darkish brown with a dark tan head.  Aroma was mostly a chocolate and some roastedness.  Flavor was much the same but the sweetness didnt overwelm the beer good job.

Nice roasted coffee aroma. Pours black, with little head. Nice body with flavors of roasted coffee finishing with a  touch of bitter hops on the finish. Very fine porter and a good value. I will by this again.

Bottle - Wow...this is just about everything I want in a beer. Dark black pour with very little head. Love the roasty smell, and the taste backs it up. Its nutty, with roasted malt, a little smoke, and bourbon lingering in the background. Mouthfeel is smooth with just enough carbonation. By far the best Ive had from Dark Horse, though I need to try more.

Bottle thanks to brentfreesh, shared with ilovedarkbeer. Pours thick for a 7.5%, with a dark brown head, black body and good lace. Aroma is a bit of biscuit, chocolate, cinnamon, vanilla, roast, alcohol and berries. Quite complex for a "regular" porter.  Taste is roasty, yeasty, some metallic notes, with lots of coffee. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation.

Bottle thanks to BMan1113VR. Thick black brown pour with some coating on the side of the glass and a small tan colored head. 

Nose is brownie, fudge, chocolate, roasted coffee, 
Mouthfeel is somewhat lighter and the finish is weaker.
Taste is roasted coffee and dark chocolate.
pours black with thin tan creamy head. the aroma was of chocolate and roasted malts. I tasted a strong coffee flavor, but was not able to taste the chocolate. was not my favorite in this style.

Pour is a black with a small creamy tan head.  Aroma is some slight chocolate with some burnt malts.  Flavor is is some coffee, chcocolate and roasted malt with a little hops on the tounge after the swallow.  A decent enough offering but nothing mind blowing.
Black in color with a small tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, caramel and cocoa. Taste is of coffee, roasted malts and dark chocolate.
On Tap. Pitch black with a tan head. Aroma: Lots of espresso and dark chocolate. Slightly sweet with pleanty of dark chocolate
On tap.  pours black with almost no head.  strong flavors of chocolate and dark heavy malts.  small notes of coffee. good full bodied beer.

Bottle.  This one will surprise you.  Pours a thin, black with little to no head.  Smell is not overwhelming or indicitive of the huge flavor.  This porter is full of burnt coffee and chocolate taste.  Great thin, clean finish from a huge robust porter.  One of the better, and stronger, porters.

Notes from Indy Winterfest.

Pours black.  Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, dark malts.  Flavors of malt, grain, chocolate and coffee.  Normal mouthfeel.  Overall a pretty good one.
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 TAP: at Happy Gnome (St. Paul, MN) on 1.31.09. Pours a dark black with a reddish/tan head. Burnt chocolate nose, flavors of roasted malt, mild chocolate. Good porter.

12 oz bottle.  Pours opaque black with a brown head.  Nice creamy aroma with chocolate, coffee, and vanilla.  Solid flavor, with notes of chocolate, coffee, and a bit of creaminess, but not comparable to the aroma.  Perhaps a little thinner than the aroma led me to expect, but this is a solid porter.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 12oz bottle.  Deep opaque black color with a minimal rusty orange head.  Mild, sweet dark chocolate malt aroma.  Medium bodied and very smooth, this is a great Black Ale.  Full of Chocolate and Roasted Malt flavors, maybe a touch of coffee.  Minimal hops as per style.  Hides the alcohol tremendously well, seems like it could be 5%.  Recommended, especially if you are into the dark side of beers.

12 oz bottle - thanks MatSciGuy! Pours black with tannish brown head that recedes quickly. Flavor is full on roasty, rich malty notes. If I didnt know any better, Id be thinking "Dry Stout." Nice synergy between the hops and the carbon from the roasting.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a thick black color with a nice sized brown head that has decent retention and nice lacing.  Aroma is heavy, heavy burnt chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.  Very rich.  Flavor is dominated by heavy roasted chocolate malts and a touch of coffee.  Very roasty!  AWESOME!  This beer is wonderful and very easy to drink, especially for how big and rich it is.  Tasty tasty.  This is NOT for those "I dont like dark beer" people.
Black pour into a shaker. Nice hear and good aroma. This is all about the malts. and is extremely quaffable. mmmmmmmmmmm

Pours black with a roasty brown head.  At first aroma is faint with hints of vanilla, cocoa and chocolate. The flavor was very smooth and had subtle fllavors of malts, semi sweet chocolate, dark fruit and coffee.

Very Well Done

12oz bottle. Poured black with a tan head. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, oat, and smoke. Taste is of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and oat. Has an underlying smoky taste. Nice lingering alcohol bite. Thick, creamy mouthfeel. A definite sipper. Very good.

DTM scored this one in trade, and we aged it for a few months before drinking (mainly because we still have too many to drink).  In any case, this one had flavors of chocolate and coffee, mostly chocolate.  Not the smoothest as there was some sourness and unbalanced something to it.

Bottle from a trade with St. Fun.  Poured a black color with a tan head. Smelled of roasted malts. Definately had the flavor of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. I little harsh on the palate to rate it with the elite, but still a great beer.
Deep dark blackish color with tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Roasty flavor, with coffee, smoke, chocolate, and a bit of sourness.  Pretty solid, pretty awesome.
Oil can black. Rich tones of darkness. Lots of body and chocolate. Sweetness lingers but it finishes with a tart taste. Porter? No, it is a stout. Come on.

Nearly opaque brown-black with a thin brown head. Dark roast coffee and chocolate aroma - malty and smoky. Chocolate and especially coffee dominate the strong flavor, with smoke and a little hops lingering on the finish. Medium body. Excellent.

A nice black beer with a head that is reddish at times.  It soon fades to a very thin layer and a small ring.  Roasted notes, chocolate, and a bit of smoke  define the aroma.  Flavor is rich chocolate and premium coffee. Some dark fruit and mild bitterness, as well.   Delicious and big, especially for a porter.  Big, robust, and delightful.

Pours dark black with a medium tan head.
Strong coffee aroma and lighter chocolate tones. Some woody hop as well. Slightly bitter coffee flavour and a  decent roast malt body if a little lighter than I had expected. Some molasses and a thin bitterness in the finish.

Bottle courtesy of KieferUGA, picked up for me while we were all up in Chicago/Indiana.  Poured a pretty viscous black with a small and short lasting light brown head.  Aroma of roasted/smoked malt, chocolate, coffee and oats.  They sure crammed a lot of flavor into this one.  Huge amounts of coffee, which I normally do not overly love, but this was really nice tasting.  Chocolate, roasted malt, caramel and darkish fruit.  A pretty solid hop presence in the finish.  Just a really stand out example of the style.

Bottle courtesy of SQNfan.  Pours black with a small dark tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma of rich roasted malt, alcohol, and bitter chocolate.  Flavor of sweet roasted malt and a hint of bitter chocolate.  A little boring, flavor-wise but ok.
12oz bottle. Jet black pour, dark tan head. Dark roasted aroma, a little chocolately as well. Nice dark roasty malt body, thicker than most porters to me, slight bitterness in the back of the throat.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 3, 2008 Bottle. Absolutely gorgeous aroma of roasted malt, coffee, espresso, supporting sweet alcohol, supporting bittering hops, working well with the coffee notes, giving them different edges. Nothing too fancy, but just everything Id want in a robust porter. Flavor works together marvelously as well, bitter chocolate, sweet coffee ice cream, perfect alcohol presence. A stand-out in a category where beers are apt to get muddled in with the masses. Mouthfeel is creamy yet airy and silky at the same time. Again, just what Im looking for, full-bodied and superbly drinkable. Is it a 5 in appearance? Tough to say...not much of a head...but this beer feels like a 5.0 to me, a glorious feeling, and the bubbles on the head that it did have were quite lively and glistening...so...a 5.0 it is.

Beer Tasting at Heritage Liquor(Maplewood, MN) - Pours black with a brown head and some spotty lacing. The nose is powdered cocoa, roasted malts, smoked barley, molasses, and a hint of coffee. Comes across the palate as charred dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, molasses, and chalky cocoa with some bittering hops in the finish. Full creamy mouth feel.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2009 Growler. Black pour with a serious brown head. A hoppy,bitter aroma. Flavor is of chocolate,and coffee as promised,lightly bitter, maybe hops or coffee , a nice smooth easy drinker. Nice body,nice mouthfeel . A very solid all around offering, and I love the Ass on the label,reminds me of mom. Thank you Dark Horse

Pours black...half finger deep tan head.  Aroma is very sweet and malty with hints of dark chocolate and mild coffee...enjoyable to take in.  Flavor is chocolate and caramel malts, roasted nuts, sweet coffee and a quick jolt of bitterness.  This was an incredibly easy drinker and a very enjoyable rendition of the style.  I was looking forward to trying this, and it didn’t disappoint!
Pours black with litle head.  Sweet fruity aroma with some mocha.  Some coffee, mocha, and hops in flavor.  Decent porter.

In short: Molasses and roasted black chocolate 
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed about six months after receiving it from my man WeeHeavySD.  Thanks a lot Jon.
The look: Black body topped by a tan ring of foam
In long: Molasses and black chocolate with high cacao content (the kind of 90%+ cacao black-chocolate).  Medium roastiness.  The strong cacao presence gives the beer a dry and floury sensation.  Its like they have used roasted black chocolate bars (if such a thing even makes sense) to make the beer.  A light lemony hops presence just isnt enough.  A little alcohol in the end once the beer as warmed up.  It is tasty and has a lot of oomph but overall the beer comes out as a simple mesh of two basic flavours and to tell you the truth the last few sips of my bottle were getting hard to enjoy.  Souts/Porters have become the workhorse of the American micros and while this one is definitely part of the horse family this is more like a well, you know, check the label.

pours very dark with little to no head, despite the brewers description...carrying a chocolate, caramel, malty aroma. not a bad flavor, but could be a little more robust..tastes similar to smell, but finishes with a slight coffee flavor. Not bad...Id consider it to be pretty good considering the county it comes from.

12oz bottle from Party Pak Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown to black with tannish, almost purple, head. Head settles quickly, but still laces the glass to some degree. Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate, some ripe dark fruit, coffee. Flavor is strongly coffee and toffee with some hints of dark chocolate and ripe raisins. Smooth and velvety with a bitter finish.

Thanks to Jason for bringing this to a tasting and leaving it!  Black pour with quickly receding tan/yellow head. Roasty, roasty, roasty aromas with tons of malt but some hop notes as well.  On the nose and palate, roasted barley, chocolate malt, molasses, some coffee bitterness, hops, and toasted hazelnuts.  Damn, this is good.

Pours thick black with brown head.  Tons of chocolate and roasted notes in the nose, a good amount of coffee, and a bit of alcohol astringency.  Lots of coffee, chocolate, and roasted notes in the flavor, some slight dark fruit and bitter hop is also present.  One of the more flavorful porters I’ve had and also one of the best.
Pours dark black with a brown head that recedes quickly.  Aroma of coffee and roasted chocolate.  Taste is very coffee with some roasted flavors.  Light lacing.  Solid stout.

The aroma of this beer was all coffee.  Anything thing else seemed roasted to the point where it too smelled like coffee.  The not surprising coffee flavor, while not overly complex, was very drinkable with some sweetness, some bite, some hoppy dryness, and lingering dark flavors of deep forest fruits.

On Tap at the Great Lakes Brewfest.  Brown to black with a frothy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, oatmeal and coffee.  Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and fruit.  Smooth and tasty with a mild bitter finish.  Yet another quality beer from the state of Michigan and Dark Horse brewery.

20 oz draft on tap at The Galway Tribes (Frankfort, IL). Pours a deep dark black, letting no light in, with a frothy brown head that almost looks like ground up chocolate it is so dark. Aromas are roasted malts, cocoa, and burnt coffee. Taste is similar, borderline med-heavy on the palate, this beer didn’t dissappoint. Roasted malts mixed with touches of chocolate and coffee and balanced with a nice bittering finish with a touch of burnt (coffee? malt?) on the end. That was the only dissappointment of this brew and quickly left my mind once I kept drinking it. Even ordered a second. Cheers!

Bottle courtesy of StFun.  Pours an opaque black with a 2 finger brown head and spotty lacing.  Nose is powdered cocoa, roasted malts, smoked barley and a touch of coffee.  Taste is charred dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans and chalky cocoa with some bittering hops in the finish.  Full creamy mouth feel.  I didnt know what to expect and this one surprised me.  Very good.  Thanks Josh!

Bottle. Pours a deep inky black with a small light brown head that fades. Crisp aroma of bitter toasted malt. Taste is bitter and clean, of burnt toasted malt, with hints of coffee and chocolate. Lingering toasted, burnt flavors. Very refreshing and tasty.

I really like this brew.  It fits my style and taste.  Malt, Chocolate, Coffee and carbonation (not too heavy)  Dark Fruit but done the way I like it.  Very enjoyable - smooth - kinda milky/creamy but with enough hops and flavor to give it some attitue.

Dark, dark black/brown color, paper thin tan head.  Strong coffee aroma matches the strong coffee taste.  First sip is all coffee, but more chocolate and toasted poppy seed bagel come in as the beer warms.  A little smoked jerky and oatmeal as it gets another degree warmer.  Finish is slightly hoppy, like flower petals.  Delicious flower petals.  Thinish body though, only complaint.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 Near black pour, healthy brown head, slight ruby around the edge.  Very roasty aroma.  Tastes roasted malt, burnt malt, oat, bakers chocolate, some smokiness.  A pleasant amount of carbonation.  Just a slight amount of hop and coffee bitterness in the finish.  Almost as much coffee in this to me as the Beer Geek Breakfast stout.  Very good and to the point of what a good porter should be.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a solid ebony colour with slight tan head and reasonable lacing. Nose- chocolate milk powder and roasted nuts. Taste- dark fruits, chocolate, touch of lactic sourness and a little smokiness. Medium bodied with a vigorous carbonation. Finishes dry.
black pour with a thin espresso head.  sweet chocolate and hint of roasted malts.  awesome thickness with a very full dark chocolate flavor with a smooth roasted malt finish.  very impressive brew.

@Indiana Beerfest-on tap-pours a rich shaving cream light brown head that laces and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-bakers chocolate/anise/roasty/some coffee, slight sharpness/acidic.  Taste is anise, sharpness/acidic, dark malt-bakers chocolate/anise/roasty/some coffee/oats.  Chewy.  Nice, but not my taste.  Occasional.

12oz bottle courtesy of mmm/beer.  This pours black with a brown head and some lacing.  Nose is of roasted malts and coffee.  Taste is more prominent than the nose and is of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel was thick and left a dry aftertaste, but no harshness at all.  Surprisingly thick for a porter. Very tasty.

Full bodied indeed. Big thick and heavy, just like the majority of Americans. Big ol’ head atop blacker than black liquidity. Dark dark dark chocolate, Colombian coffee mixed with dark fruits and roasted grain. Delicious. Will certainly keep me coming back.

What a way to start the first Saturday of college football.  The wife and kids are at the in-laws place, I have the Big Ten Network in HD, and this evening will be my first time meeting the Indianapolis RateBeer community.  I’m jacked up.  So I though I’d sit down on my own and try a beer that I probably should have had long ago.

The pour is pitch black with a thick brown head.  A real nice layer of brown lace is left behind.  Fairly nice aroma of roast, cream, berries, and a bit of chocolate.  It reminds me of one of those canned coffee drinks.  Strong, aggressive roasted flavor and very bitter.  Med/full body with small carbonation bubbles that gives the beer a gritty mouthfeel.  Long, bitter, roasted finish.  Lots of character here.  Pretty robust, yet easy to drink.

M Go Blue!!!

Black color with a good tan colored head.  Smells of roast, burnt malts, coffee, and chocolate.  Taste is a good roasted malt flavor, some darker malts, and coffee at the back of the mouth.  Good beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a super thin tan head.  You can hear the fizziness as the carbonation releases.  Very rich super malty aroma of milk chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor has a strong roast character with a bitter dark chocolate and cofffee finish.  Very nice, this is not over powering but the flavors are all vibrant.  Full creamy feel.

Pours opaque black with a mocha colored, dense head that struggles out of solution.
The inch-tall foam sank slowly, leaving behind a thick wall of clingy lace. Traces of mahogany luminescence around the edges.

Aromatics start off with dark chocolate, espresso, roasted malts, and cocoa.
Brownie batter and a hint of nougat follow through.
