Tastes like it smells with a salty finish and bitter burnt malt & licorice aftertaste. Lots of hoppiness in the end as well-a bit too much in fact... Full bodied. Medium carbonation. I would like this better with less hops....

Thanks for this one Jason!  Nose is coffee with some caramel and a high olfactory density, slightly milky.  Nice flavour.  Aftertaste is very bitter, enough to rival some IPAs.  There is some roast here, a nice woody earth tone.  I really enjoy this beer.
12 oz bottle. Poured almost black with no head. Smells very nice, but the taste doesnt match. Very bitter with an aftertaste of burnt coffee. A bit too harsh, even for a porter.

Bottle from Sean (illinismitty) or Chris (styles) Thanks both of you guys.  Pours out very dark almost black with a tan head that goes away quick.  Smell is rich and full of coffee and chocolate with some hints of vanilla.  Taste is similar, very rich and the alcohol isnt noted alot even though it is fairly high for a porter.  It doesnt pass off as sweet as alot of porters that get into the higher abv range do, which is great.  Really enjoyed this one, and Im glad I have one more bottle to drink this winter with a fat cigar.

Dark Horse Reserve Special Black Bier Ale
12 oz bottle
Recent brewing, arsed over 11/06
Medium pour in an English pint

Poured black with a moderate light brown frothy somewhat lasting head with a tiny ring of lacing.

Smelt of strong nuttiness, mild coffee and cream, mild chocolate, with vanilla cola notes.

Taste was upfront strong bitter coffee and burnt taste with light sweet molasses, followed by a harsh burnt taste and moderate coffee, licorice and nuttiness, on a long bitter burnt finish.  Mouthfeel was medium to full bodied, creamy, lively carbonated, with harsh astringency.

Overall, a harsh and not so subtle beer.  It smells and looks wonderful, but doesnt beg to please the tastebuds.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a settling woody head.  Faint bittersweet chocolate, a touch of french roast and cider.  Creamy body with just a slight back tongue tingle.  Sour raisins soaked in espresso.  Builds into a dry bitterness.  Well disguised hops burst through.  Interesting take on the style.

Oil like pour with no head at all, Sticky on the lips. Alcohol is very well hidden! Very hoppy for a Porter! A really nice drink for me, the best of both worlds, Hoppy, roasted, Sweet,delicious! Thanks to Duane for the bottle!

Pours black with a thin tan head and thick lacing. Aroma is of rounded roast, an oily sweetness, a mild chocolate,  a bit of biscuit and a soft touch of soy. Flavor is a rolling mixture of a very deep roast coffee, semisweet chocolate, dark chocolate, and biscuity malt. Pretty rich. Medium body with a very slightly watery palate. Aftertaste is a a nice mix of roast, semisweet chocolate, and biscuit.

Bottle from Duane.  Poured midnight black with almost no head, just a small tan rim around the edge of the cup.  Piney hops and lots of heavily roasted malts in the nose.  First taste is a pretty overpowering amount of roasted flavors, but once your tongue gets used to it, this is a pretty smooth drinking beer.    Roasted barley followed by a pretty dry, hoppy finish.  Very tasty porter.

Pours a very dark oily brown with a decent sized head. The aroma is of heavy roast and chocolate. Heavy roast, coffee, and subtle bittersweet bakers chocolate coat the tongue. No trace of hops. Quite a bit of body for a .....wait, what is this supposed to be? More stoutish than Porter, definitely not Shwartzbier. Very dry roasty bitter aftertaste. Body is somewhat oily. Alcohol is nicely masked.

Coffee and roasted barley aroma, black as can be, roasted coffeeish, taste with a touch of licorice, lots of roastedness in the aftertaste, Definitely not a schwarz, body is less then medium, that roasted,almost burnt taste is wonderful, gets a very dry and bitter in the finish. This stuff is special

roasted barley,  malts, and too much molasses, and bit of berry and not enough hoppiness for me. Yet is was pleasingly dry and bitter and creamy, sort of oily.  I want to try more from this brewer. Are they intentionally trying to confuse via the label what this is? Goofy donkey cartoon label seems odd for this ambitious brew.

I picked this out of my "cellar" (a box in my garage), having focused entirely on the "black bier" and thinking that it was a schwarzbier.  As soon as I poured it, I knew that wasnt right, because it was so opaque, black, and oily that I looked at the bottle and saw "ale".  It is deep with roast, burnt notes and a fair degree of hops, akin to a Rogue stout.  The palate suggests more body that a porter, quite clearly.  The palate is luscious and compelling, though the bitterness of the finish prevents this from being a "fast drinker".  Still, it is a well crafted brew, whatever its style.

12 oz bottle thanks to sprinkle.  Lots of chocolate and roasty malt aroma coming off of this very black beer with a nice tan head.  Flavors are very similar in bittersweet chocolate and some coffee.  Burnt malt after taste too.  One of my favortite porters so far.

The pour reveals a deep black color with a thin creamy light brown head. Rich and sweet aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Very good flavor of chocolate, hops and roasted malt with a solid bitter finish, its assertive and well-done. The body has a light to medium thickness with a dry mouthfeel and soft carbonation. A superb porter.

12 oz. bottle via trade with 1Fast STi - Pours a deep dark brown color with a nice tan head.  Spotty lacing.  Has a nice coffee, chocolate aroma.  Has a strong roasted malt flavor.  Leaves a dry, bitter aftertaste.  Medium body.  As porters go, this one is a little too bitter and dry for my liking.  Still, a good beer overall.  Thanks Blake.
Dark color.  Smell of roasted coffee, oatmeal, malt and some hops.  Tastes of hops, sweet chocolate, coffee, rye and oatmeal with a nice dry bitterness.  Nice differnt beer.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a cartoon moose (my friend splitting this with me claims its a mule) on the front label, no bottled/freshness date.

Good start, poured a opaque blackish brown with a foamy, fluffy tan head that settled into a thin foamy, skim-like lacing, good laced sticking.

Aromas of roasted barley and malts, molasses and a berry fruitiness, and a subtle herbal hoppiness. Also light whiffs of alcohol.

Good moderate stout carbonation and a crisp, dryish, slick and creamy smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

Big tastes of roasted barley and grains, a coffee maltiness, a berry fruitiness, raisins and prune juice, molasses sweet, a light herbal spicy hoppiness, the alcohol shows up towards the end giving the taste a bit of a bite, and a dry roasted malty finish.

A tasty and balanced double stout from Dark Horse, a good sipper, dangerously quaffable, well worth trying.

The labeling of this beer confused me. I was under the impression I was buying a Schwarzbier. After looking this one up, I found out it was a porter. After pouring it in the glass, I realized it was actually a stout by any conventional and modern use of the term. This one has a great nose of raisons, something else sweet that my inadequate descriptive abilities cant peg, and some roasted malt. Tan thin head on top of jet black beer. Very roasty and a little too thick. This is no porter, more of an Imperial Stout if you ask me. Had some alcohol on the back end that wasnt quite enjoyable. This is a good beer in a style I dont really like.

Bottle thanks to Styles!  Poured a medium-viscocity black with a fairly well-retained cap of caramel head.  Nose picked up a solid array of dark almost burnt malts (molasses, dark chocolate, raisin, and some soy) with herbal spices and hops... very nice.  Burnt dark chocolate, coffee, and soy come on heavy at the front of the palate with herbs, anise, and alcohol pushing through the back end.  Solid levels of acidity and coffee bitterness surround the tongue and carry through the finish.  Heavier on the palate.  Very nice brew!

I find myself thanking Beerdrenched yet again for picking a treat up for me.  Pours close to black with a small dark orange head.  Aroma is wonderful - roasted and creamy with vanilla, chocolate, anise and other spices - smells like dessert in a glass.  Starts out rich and medium bodied with burnt roasted malt and some some and hoppy spice.  The finish has lots of spicy hops and tons of roastedness.  On the finish the mouthfeel is much lighter.  Very nicely done beer.

GTMW 06.  Dark brown body, dark tan head.  Chocolate roast and grahm cracker in the aroma.  Nice munich, roasted barley, and sweet chocolate flavor.  Light noble bittering hops at the end.  A damn fine beer.

Near black with a taller dense tan head. Toasty malt and dark chocolate lead in the nose. Fairly simple in aroma, but very enticing and welcoming. Full dark chocolate and bitter coffee flavors. The best thing is that the bitterness mellows to just a mild acidic dry cleansing finish. Full and rich feel that gets thinned out a touch by the black malt acidity. Depending on the time this one "swills" about the mouth, the bitterness varies. If you take a quick hit, the bitterness is less pronounced and only a short after thought. Let the brew set on the tongue and the acid oozes out and dries the tongue and wears the palate out. A very nice black brew.

Pitch black pour with a frothy tan head.  Aroma consists of coffee, chocolate, sugar, nice roasted malt notes, light caramel, and nicely hoppy.  What is most prevalent in the taste is first the coffee and chocolate notes,  then the roasted malt textures come through with the hoppiness.  Palate is bitter/sweet, long, and full bodied.  Overall, This ranks up there with the Fullers London Porter I rated a while ago. This Packs a bigger punch though.  Very, Very nice Porter!!!!

beer practically oozes out, thick and black with a dense brown head that doesnt retain so well but leaves good lace.  smell of boozy chocolate-rum balls, with perhaps some other complex roast aromas filling in around the edges.  flavor starts somewhat sweet and chocolate-y but begins to dry to a roasty finish, which is punched up by some not insignificant hop bitterness.  lots of big flavors in this stout, but they are fairly well balanced against each other. very nice mouthfeel.

Michigan Brewers Festival 2006. Black body with a nice creamy tan head that fades a bit. Moderate sweet roast aroma. Flavour starts with mild dark roast and is fairly dry, with more sweet dark malt in the foundation. Average palate. Solid beer but not for me. 7/4/6/3/13-15

(Bottle via trade with BBB63, thanks Mike!) Pours black as night, a few microscopic ruby highlights fight through the opaqueness. About 1/2" of light brown head recedes to about 1/8". Aroma is coffee with cream, sweet chocolate, roasted coffee beans and some hints of grape. Mouthfeel smooth, lightly oily. Spotty lacing. Big coffee/chocolate flavor. Bit of grassiness in finish. Darn good, seemed very close to a sweet stout.
A Nice high-gravity porter.  An aroma of coffee and malts.  A very dark bodied beer with an almost negligable head.

12-oz. bottle from artusory.  Pours dark black, near opaque, with a tiny tan head that clings to the edges.  Aroma is dark and sweet chocolate and caramel malts, yeast (leather), charcoal, coffee.  Moderately bitter and acidic dark chocolate and coffee flavor, slight smokiness, finish is sour.  Dark bodied and smooth dry palate.

Finally a beer that has something going for it.  Pours black with a nice looking mocha head.  Aroma with rich coffee with cream and roasted malt...a bit of burnt chocolate comes in as it warms.  Flavor is loaded with robust and bitter coffee...quite a lot of red fruit comes through as well...this is the only DH beer that has had any complexity.  Mouthfeel is thick and oily.  This beer is much more of a stout than a porter...but I dig it.

the last of our Dark Horses.  A pretty good one to end on considering the range we experienced.   Not sure "porter" is accurate.  Alcohol and flavor are more intense for the simplicity of a "porter."  okay, this gets a lot better when it warms.  it moves from good to terriffic.  Pours black with a one finger brown head.   Just huge chocolate roasted malts all over the place and totally masking the 8% abv.  Great beer, complex and tasty.  Lasting bitterness after the swallow.

a bit too bitter in flavor for me.  its pretty close to a weaker imperial stout.  beautiful elegent appearance.  aroma is pretty terrific, but the taste is just a bit too bitter and empty (otherwise) for me.

Bottle. Pours oily black, with a diminishing plummy brown head. Nice aroma of dark roasted malt, molasses, coffee, and hardwood mulch. Good initial flavor of burnt dark chocolate, brown sugar, and dark roasted malt. The finish is dry and bitter, with very pronouced roasted coffee flavors that linger.Parts of this beer remind me of 2004 MendocinoWinter (Porter). Whatever you do, do NOT drink this too cold.

Roasted malts and bitterness dominate this porter. Inky black pour with short, tan head. The aroma is mostly burnt malt, but underneath are notes of chocolate and coffee. After a swirl, you get a whiff of earthiness that seems out of place. The flavor is hefty on charred malts with a hint of licorice. That gives way to a bittnerness, somewhat reminiscent of strong, burnt, bitter coffee. The finish is dry. Medium to thick body seems heavier than a stout, more like an imperial stout than a porter. Sticky palate and a long, bitter finish.

Pitch black, nice sized creamy tan head.  Looks like a stout!  Looks wonderful regardless.  What a lovely roast aroma with hints of smoke and hops.  Taste - wow, incredibly flavourful.  Porter roast taste comes through at first with a hint of sweetness and a bit of acidic sourness.  This is followed up by a ton of flavour - more roast, this time more coffee like, dry bakers chocolate, and a good dose of hops.  Seems thinner at first before exploding into a robust body.  Long lingering roast and bitterness.  Wow, big thanks to Hogtown Harry for the bottle.  This is instantly one of my favourites!

Black, bitter, roasty, tasty.  Not much complexity or anything, its just dark, good and delicious.  I love how bitter it is.  Hops and dark grains both contribute to that, and it works great.  Some alcohol in the aroma, but none in the flavor.  Get some if you can.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2012 5/22/06 From a bottle purchased at the Beer Depot in Ann Arbor.
Pours a powerful viscous black with a modestly-sized deep brown head and abundant lacing.
 The beer provides a nice big aroma: roasting coffee, dark plums, molassas, and a hint of smoke. The smoke dominates my first impression of the flavor, coming on much harder than expected with a taste of smoked almonds tinged throughout with tendrils of sweet dark malt, plenty of fruit rounding out the late middle of the sip, and bittering into a lovely hopped finish still fronting plenty of thai-iced-coffee sweetness. The mouthfeel is plain perfect. 
Darn Im impressed by this beer and I wish I could get it on a regular basis.

7/16/12Revisit, bottle from Whole Foods in Ann Arbor. Yep, worthy. More ash than I noted on the first past, but absolutely delicious. I might go more like 4.1 on this, but Ill let the original stand.

pours a sinfully black... looks and smells like a strong stout. the hoppiness is the only thing that could explain why this wasnt labeled as an imperial porter... well, that and its abv. roasted malts and hint of acidity... almost an espresso-like acidity actually. hop profile balances nicely, esp. w/ the carbonation. another first rate beer from dark horse.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2006 pours thick black looks like a stout. no light is getting through this one. small brown head that goes away quickly. huge aroma. roasted malts dominates with some licorice something slightly acidic. flavor just as big as aroma. very bitter coffee flavor slightly salty and acidic. body medium. finish very bitter roasted coffee. very appropriate carbonation not too much not too little.  fantastic beer.

A solid porter. Pours black and has malty aroma. Flavors are sweet and bitter, they compliment each other well. It is the hint of something smoky and sour in both the aroma and flavor that I can do without.

Black bodied with a brown head, this has an aroma filled with sweet roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and a drop or two of coffee.  Creamy.  The flavor is a bit sweeter with the addition of molasses and is lightly bittered by almonds.  Sticky finish with a modest hit of earthy bitterness.  Nice.U.S.A. rating #1234!<font size=-4>Thanks to the generosity of RateBeerians at the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve Lord Release- Three Floyds, Munster, IN - 04/29/2006<font size=-1>

Nice dark black pour. Wiht maybe a slight red touch. Nice creamy looking tan head as well. Very smooth and creamy mouthfull. Not a whole lot of taste in my opinion. Slight coffee, molasses, hops, and alcohol notes. A little to bitter for my taste. Not one of my favs. But drinkable.

Black coffee pour.  The nose is real roasty, with a touch of dark chocolate and charred cookie.  Thick mouthfeel is appropriate.  Lots of bakers chocolate throughout, leaving my tongue chalky.  A nutty layer persists under the chocolate, helping to sweeten things.  A slight sharp bitterness in the finish is nice contrast for this otherwise smooth brew.

Draft at Dark Horse. Poured a black color with an average creamy light brown head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate sweet toasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy texture. Well balanced sweet toasted malt flavor with a smooth moderate bitter finish of long duration. Very pleasing brew.

bottle. pours a deep dark black body with a medium-sized frothy mocha head. Top notch aroma of vanilla bean, rye bread, milk chocolate, and toffee. Full-bodied, flavourful stuff to say the least. Lots of roasty malt flavour with general coffee and lots of rich chocolate notes. finishes with intensely bitter chocolate and toffee essence. Delicious! Bought at Bello Vino in Ann Arbor in April 2006.

Pours opaque black with a two finger foamy tan head that dissipates quickly, moderate lacing. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, smoke, molasses, soy sauce. Flavor is very roasty with semi sweet chocolate, molasses, coffee, vanilla, smoke and a gentle hop zing in the finish. Seems very well balanced, absolutely delicious. Mouthfeel is substantial for a porter, moderately creamy and slightly oily with gentle carbonation. Is this really a porter? Ill take this over many stouts any day, great stuff.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of HogTownHarry. First beer of our Dark Horse Brewing tasting. Pours a murky bubbly black with a spare light-brown head. Slightly roasty aroma of caramel malt, chocolate, vanilla, hops and an interesting spice that I cant place -- very nice! Flavour of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and a nice hoppy finish. I found the aftertaste had a slight metallic taste to it, subtle but still there, perhaps the bottle was slightly past its prime? Nice full body, especially for a Porter. This was a pleasant surprise, a very good Porter and a fine start to our DH tasting.

My second Dark Horse brew and another threat.  Thanks to Tom and Nancy (mamabeer) for sharing.  Pours out very black with a nice brown head.  The nose is semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, with some ripe berries and a touch of citrus hops, all of which carry over to the flavor.  Rich and full in the mouth.  Smooth.  This Dark Horse seems to be a winner.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, my bottle, from Pintbypint.  Poured thick opaque brown-black with a minimal but dark brown head.  Wonderful aroma, very roasty, rich and oily - chestnuts, dark chocolate, burnt caramel malt, but most surprising was  this incredible hot cinnamon (and some vanilla) spiciness blended with strong resiny hops.  Taste was much more bitter than I expected, not near as much spice in the flavour, mostly burnt chocolate and coffee roastiness followed by a big kick of bitter resiny hops on the longish finish; unfortunately, there was an increasing tang of bottle metal as it warmed - maybe a less than fresh bottle?  This had a very muscular body - more like an Impy Stout than a porter - with a flat, acidic quite complex mouthfeel - terrific beer, if this is really a porter, one of the best Ive had - would like to try it again with a guaranteed fresh bottle to compare.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a trace of a tan head.  The aroma is full of coffee malts and a little chocolate.  The taste is a nice balance of coffee and chocolate, with a little roasted malt flavor.  Very full bodied.  I was a bit confused whether this was a black beer or a porter....

Black color with a thin head.  Good aroma of coffee and chocolate.  The coffee really piles up in the taste with a dry chocolate and slightly burnt malt base.  Dry and bitter finish.  I honestly thought it was a light Imperial Stout.  Damn tasty!

MI brewers guild fest/06. Opaque black, with just a hint of light reaching through. Looks like a stout to me! Charred malt upfront in the nose, roasted coffee, dark rum , with oakey booze following. Spiced dark rum flavours aside bitter coffee beans, dark chocolate with oaked woodiness. A solid brew from one of the best at the fest!

On tap at the brewpub.  These guys know how to do dark beers.  Dark black with a foamy beige head with rocky rivers running through it.  Charred wood, coffee, molasses, dark fruits and good hop kick to boot.  Wow.

Beautifully brewed porter in every way.  Great black oily pour.  Intense roasted aroma.  Very pronounced roasted (make that, "burnt") flavors...dried fruits, raisins, figs, dates, espresso, molasses, and brown sugar.  Hop bitterness there throughout, but strengthens in the finish.  Enjoyed with El_ Borracho while touring the brewery.  We drank, we looked at each other,  and we said, "This might be my new favorite brewpub!"

Thanks to Sully for this one. Poured pitch black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet fruits and coffee. I actually noticed that pear seemed to be the dominant fruit. Flavor was mostly dark fruit: raisin and fig with some hints of chocolate. Chalky mouthfeel and slightly bitter and dry in the finish. Reminded me of the Hercule Stout, but better.

Very thick and rich for a porter...looks inviting!  Great aroma:  a lot of chocolate and even some espresso...a good dose of malts and vanilla.  I really like it!  The flavor is robust and more like an imperial porter, definetly.   Great, creamy and thick mouthfeel.  The vanilla comes through in the flavor, as does the coffee.  Perfectly roasty.  Yum!

Many thanks to OhioDad for this one - opaque pour with substantial, dark tan lace - very smokey aroma, with large amounts of  coffee and sweet cream - very smooth, almost oily mouthfeel - quite bitter and roasty, huge coffee notes - plum, vanilla, cream - some hop bitterness at the end compliments the dark roast coffee flavors - a great porter.

Courtesy of Sprinkle.

Damn this poured like an Impy! Aroma is roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Deep black with a thin mocha head. Fore is very bitter with lots of coffee notes..hints of sweet cream in the middle along with quality milk chocolate and malt..the finish is again bitter with a big coffee finish. Intense flavor in this porter that could easily pass as a stout.

Bottle from Sully Thanks!  Pours a rich, oil-like black with minimal head and clinging lace.  Aroma is wooden chocolate with a touch of smoke.  Flavor is an onslaught of coffee, chocolate, hops, and bitterness.  Smooth palate; very slick and clingy on the taste buds.  A seemingly simple porter in the onset that develops complexity as it lingers on the tongue.  Great beer!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 WOW! This poured black with a thick creamy brown head. Left really great lacing. Nose seamed to be roasted chocolate, some dark fruits, and cream.  Taste was a surprising alcohol kick. Did not know the 8%. There was roasted malts, coffee, raisins, and licorice. This was some bitter hops to make this a very well balanced brew.  Thank you so much Sully. This is great. What is missing from this is that sickening sweetness. This is really good.

yep, its black alright. a brown bubbled watery head sits atop it. roasted coffee nose. a bit of chocolate too and the caramel aroma of spilled dr pepper on a hot hibachi grill. roast is the dominant flavor too. chocolate and blue bell homemade vanilla flavored ice cream. some peanut butter in the finish. very nice balancing bitter that stays in the background out of the way and allows me to enjoy the dark malts and richness of this. this has a rich flavor, but a surprisingly light mouthfeel. a nice brew that i will happily take in a trade again. thanks, adam(atpayne)

12oz bottle via trade with sprinkle - Thanks Mike!  - Pours thick like oil,  black as night, with a creamy mocha head that stays around for a short time but laces down.  Nice aroma of coffee, a touch of molasses, caramel, and chocolate.  Flavor is roasty.. Lots of roasted and burnt notes, coffee, chocolate, molasses, a hint of licorice.  Palate is thick and chewy with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel.  This is liquid from the Gods.. Very nice stuff..

Sampled at the monthly meeting of the Champaign-Urbana Beer Club courtesy of Tom and Nancy (mamabeer). Thanks! Going into it, I was thinking this was a black ale and was pleasantly surprised when it came out to be a whole lot more. Notes of tar and sweet coffee on the nose lead into a think and extracted porter, with a solid roastedness and sweetness. Semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, and a bite from the hops meet up on the palate. A solid finish. Well done.

12oz bottle at Box Bar. Pours a thick oily dark dark black with almost no head. Nose is extreme roast, espresso, malt, molasses, and licorice. Taste is syrupy, very thick and clingy. Lots of chocolate, coffee, more malted milk balls, and lots of roast.

Black. Small brown head. Pours like motor oil. Roasty, burnt, chocoffee, malt, licorice-aroma. Similar flavor with some cola and subtle spices, hops coming through also. Complex. Full, smooth body. Bitter chocoffee finish. Unique brew. Excellent.

Very dark brown, thick body with minimal tan/orange head that leaves some nice lacing.  Aromas are heavy of dark malt, coffee and chocolate. The aroma flavors come through strongly in the tasting, but they are all pretty bitter.  Coffee is more like espresso, chocolate is unsweetened chocolate, and malt flavors are slightly burnt, perhaps excentuated by the bitterness from the hops.  Mouthfeel is silky but dry.  Well balanced... maybe a little too bitter for some, but an excellent offering from Dark Horse.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle.  dark black, aroma of chocolate and coffee.  flavor is rich chocolates, roasted malts and coffee.  This is a great beer.  It may be my new favorite.

12 oz bottle, via MAP.  Dark black pour with a small short lived chocolate brown head.  Chocolate and roasted malt aroma, hints of coffee.  Flavor is a mix of bakers chocolate and coffee nicely balanced with hop bitterness.  Finish is coffee as well, with alcoholic warmth.  Full bodied and chewy with an oily texture and fine bottle conditioned carbonation.  Pretty robust for a porter, bordering on Imperial Stout territory.  Alot of depth to the flavor.  Second beer from Dark Horse, and second winner.

Bottle from Styles.  The beer pours to a very black body with a thin dark brown head.  The aroma is very strong dark bitter chocolate and roasty malts.  Vanilla and coffee.  The flavor is a very drying charcoal and chocolate.  Reminds me of Brooklyn BCS.  I like this a lot.  The palate is drying and medium full bodied.

Black pour thick creamy brown head nice lacing.  Aroma strongly of roasted malts, alcohol, coffee, & a light bitter chocolate note.  Palate is well coated a touch sticky lightly creamy.  Flavor is almost a stout.  Lots of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate touches of alcohol and vanilla even a little salty.  Pretty darn good.
Thick syrupy texture with a strong coffee nose.  Roasted malt flavors are smooth and silky with a hint of vanilla.  The finish is roasty and slightly bitter with a hint of spice.

Rich coffee and roasted chocolate aroma, mingled with a hint of wood and vanilla sugar. Pours a oil dark black, with a coffee and cream head. Mellowed coffee flavor and a hint of mole with pumpkinseeds and fresh chocolate. Oily, sweet and slick. Has a wonderful aromatic vanilla and cream quality, over a more reserved roastedness. Finish is a little salty and oaty, with plenty of appropriate dryness.

Thanks to Secret Santa for this beer.  Poured  black with a creamy brown head.  Aroma of bitter roasted coffee and chocolate-covered cherries.  Taste is mildly sweet with roasted bittersweet choclate dominating and a touch of fruitiness topped off with some citrus and pine hops, leading to a dry bitter finsih.  Roasty, bitter, and good.

Thanks Santa!  Another plesant surprise from Dark Horse.  Pours black as night with a tan head.  Mild aroma of malt and alcohol.  Creamy in the mouth.  Nice balanced flavor with a smoky finish and coffee aftertaste.  Very good!
(Bottle)  Pours an opaque, black body with a spare light brown head.  Aroma of roasted coffee.  Flavor of roasted coffee, hiops, and chocolate with a bitter finish.

deep dark brown color. rich tan head. Aroma faint, but roasty and chocolate. Flavor is thin up front developing into a full somewhat roasty but mostly bitter punch. A little more harsh of a porter than I am used to.

This porter pours an eclipse black color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is chocolate, roasty nearly burnt malts and coffee. A medium to full bodied porter. Malts are very roasty, nearly burnt with lots of chocolate and coffee flavors. Slightly spicy hops. Smooth taste. Lots of roasty flavors. Found this beer buried in the back of the fridge, a pleasant surprise. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and dry. Aftertaste is bitter.
Bottled. Rather black coloured. Malty and roasty aroma with fruity notes. Roasty flavour with notes of chocolate. Dry and bitter finish. Nice.

Pitch black colored with a foamy brown head. Hard roasted aroma with coffee and liquorice. Strong and warming from the alcohol. Dry coffee and roasted flavor, biding on the tongue with a sour edge from the roasted malt. A bit short in the finish, but all in all a lovely beer!

Pours thick black with small but compact brown head.  Roasted and chocolate malts and a hint of coffee in the aroma.  Very bold, nice assortment of aromas.  The initial flavor is an up front malt sweetness, and were it not followed by a solid roasted and coffee malt and a coffee and hop led bitterness, it would be too sweet.  Fortunately the mentioned malts and bitterness give it a very nice ballance.  As it warms it gets a more gritty roasted malt but continues with the strong sweetness.  Nice finish, mostly leaving a roasted flavor in the mouth.

jet black appearance with tiny reddish-brown head....aroma of roasted notes (chocolate, coffee, molasses)....flavor is quite the same with a smokiness to it.....a tad bitter of an aftertaste....perfect creamy palate

Good roasty,bitter chocolate and molassas nose.  Black as night,thick lace but no head.  Rich, dark malt bombard your palate, huge but balanced.  Im not the biggest porter fan but this is one big porter, its nice when you can sip on a beer and wait a minute and the flavor is still with you. This beer could handle some age and thats what I intend to do.

12oz - Aroma is sweet roasted chocolate malt.  Pours a deep black with a brown ring for head and decent lacing.  Flavor is intense roasted chocolate malt and thick molasses.  Palate is creamy and thick.  Very tasty dense beer.

Dark black pour with tan head that kind of lingers for awhile.  Aroma big on roasted malt, chocolate, as well as coffee and caramel.  Flavor lets the hop presence in a bit, but mostly the big roast and chocolate seem to stick to the taste buds.  Rock solid entry from Dark Horse.

12oz. bottle.  Nearly opaque black, thin film of dark tan head.  Caramelized sugar, nuts, and tinges of roast coffee in the aroma.  Chocolate and roast malt flavors.  Coffee and roasty astringency in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and fairly dry.  More roasted character than I would anticipate in a porter.

I thought the name of this beer was deceiving, I was expecting a black lager. (Side note: DH REALLY needs to spend some coin on their label art.)  Poured black, with a chocolate, soapy head.  Aroma of chocolate, malt and piney hops.  Tastes are pretty much the same. Tastes like a stout to me.

Huge aroma aroma of burnt molasses and dried fruit.  Very black pour, slightly thin, with an off-white head.  Very roasted, burnt ash flavor, some sweetnessof cherries, and a little alcohol.  Nice bier.  Thanks Brad.

Bottle.  Opaque black pour.  Big chocolate and dark fruit aromas and flavors, and some roasted notes and caramelly molasses  too.  This is, imo, a hybrid porter-stout, and man is it good.  Fairly thick for a porter, but still really good.

Pours a used motor oil black. Theres absolutely no light getting through this one. Has a thin dark brown head, with small amounts of lacing.

Smells of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts. What you would expect from a good stout.

Taste is initially chocolate, followed by the coffee and roasted malts finishing with just a touch of bitter hops and alcohol. This one is better that I had anticipated. Mouthfeel is just thick enough to let you know that you are drinking a stout, but so much that its hard to finish.

My first beer from Dark Horse, and I was pleasantly surprised. Cant wait to try the others in my fridge.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: A black beer with a huge brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of chocolate, alcohol, and cardboard, while the flavor is sweet roasted with notes of chocolate, and a dry roasted end.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2005 Pours jet black with a dark tan head. Mostly lasting, some lacing. Aroma is big with chocolate and coffee. Flavor is bitter dark chocolate, coffee, rosted malt, molasses with a big hop presence. Full bodied with a smooth velvety texture. Flavor fills the mouth for a very long finish.

Bottled: Pitch black coloured. Dense dark brown head. Roast and light sweetness and malt in the aroma. Light liqourice. Flavour of sweetness, coffee, roast and malt. A bit artificial. Ends on a dry coffeish note.

BOttled. Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a brown head, Aroma is roasted, sweet malts and toasted bread. Taste is roasted, very roasted, with a long roasted aftertaste. A very nice beer. Thanks to EyedrinkAle for this trade.

Aroma of toasted barley, musty old dates that have been sitting with rusty nails for a while and then a hint of chocolate.  Dark, almost black brown with an inch tall, lovely brown head.  Initial flavor of roasted barley, medium bitter with a touch of metallic chocolate and raisins in the finish.  Medium body, slightly watery side of creamy with a dry, bitter, metallic finish. Bottle, thanks to EyeDrinkAle.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2005 Couleur noire foncée, mousse beige aux grosses bulles savonneuses.  Arômes de chocolat, de noix, de vanille et de rôti.  Levuré en bouche, bon profil de malt rôti, chocolat et anis.  Finale toujours signée par le rôti se terminant sur une note très amère.  Texture huileuse, corps dépaisseur moyenne à pleine, réchauffement de la part de lalcool.  Michigan brewers fest, Ypsilanti, Michigan, Juillet 2005.
Very roasty nose with nice honts of brandy. Jet black body, small tan head. Extreme roasty flavor, good brandy flavor. Good one.

Tap: At dark horse brewery. Wonderful jet black color with nice thin head dissipating quickly. Nice lacing. A big beer for a porter, very rich with loads of molasses and other sweet notes at first taste, surprisingly smooth as it finishes, nicely balanced hops accompany this awesome beer. One of my favorites to date.

From the bottle, it smells like a stout.  Black with a dark, creamy head that lasts quite a while.  Malty chocolate flavor, a bit of a pepper aftertaste.  The aftertaste leaves you puckering your lips like youve just eaten something sour (but there is no sour taste).  Thick mouthfeel, I would have rated it higher except for the aftertaste.

Surprise bottle courtesy of styles: Totally opaque black in the glass with a small, yet thick and lasting, brown head that lasts.  The aroma actually shows a slight hops scent if served way too cold (which I did then let it warm up).  Once its reached the proper temperature notes of sweet toffee, chocolate, de-bittered roasted malt, earthy coffee, cinnamon, cookie dough, and a hint of diacetyl.  I dive in.  It turns out that my nose did not deceive me - there appears to be more hops in here than the average porter.  At first I get a hint of citrus/pine & alcohol mixed with a roasted coffee.  Then the beer opens up to show black pepper, roasted malt, unsweetened chocolate, charred tree bark, charcoal covered in molasses.  Full bodied, oily & thick, sticky in the mouth.  Finishes with bitter roasted malt, coffee, and a hint of hops on the tongue.  If I had to guess Id say there was some columbus or cascade in this one along with some british hops, which provides an interesting contrast to the roasted malt - similar to a well-hopped imperial stout (alpha-klaus, but less hops).  Thanks Chris!

Pours completely black with a big brown bubbly head. Sweet chocolate and deep roasted coffee and chewy malts with a little tart. Lots of crud at the bottom of the glass. Oily and burnt. Sour with bittersweet sugar. Butterfat and a good dose of hop bite up front. Charred wood, oatmeal and molasses. Very big and deep for a porter. Lovely.

Thanks to Mike (EDA) for this one.  One of the darkest black beers ever- especially for a porter.  This is a great imperial porter- yet not a baltic porter.  Similar to gonzo I guess but the dark horse has way less hops.  Aroma is intense with chocolate malt, rich caramel, and a lot of nuts.  Flavor is also nutty with a ton of chocolate to it.  So close to an impy stout just without the roasted barley.  Mouthfeel is big bold and sticky.  Very smooth and slightly bitter aftertaste.

Bottle acquired in trade with Styles (thanks!). Poured a dark black with a smaller sized brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and molassest. Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts and I swear there is some citrus in there with an almost grapefruit bitter finish to it. Oily body.

Finally rating this after trading it away plenty of times. Pours dark black, a little oily, with nice beige head. Aroma is full of dark roasted grain, coffee, and faint chocolate. Lots of creamy milk chocolate in the flavor, along with some coffee and a strong bitterness in the finish. Better body than many stouts Ive had. Looking at the different reviews, seems a bit inconsistant.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Comes close to being pitch-black, completely opaque. Small, light brown head. Nose full of burned malt, flavours full of burned malt and lots of bitterness from the burned malt. Surprisingly light-bodied - almost a bit watery - with a very dry finish. Has some vinous touches. 170705
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small baige head. Roasted malty chocolate aroma and a roasted malty dry coffee taste. Medium body and a dry finish.

Bottled.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of coffee and liquorice with notes of chocolate.
Roasted flavour with lots of chocolate and coffee.
Dark brown body with a light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with a chocolate sweetness. Roasted malty flavor with coffee notes.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2006 Freshly distributed bottle, August 2006.
Thick black pour with a preceding minimal hiss from the cap being lifted.  Splotchy and large tan bubbles circle the wrung as a mahogany lightened edge shines through.  Deep dark treats transcend aromatics.  Black turtle fudge, tar, espresso grinds and bitter, unsweetened bakers chocolate all take turns at seducing the sniffer. Flavor brings out an even more bittered edges, cutting and cunning the tongue as it weaves through the unsweetened chocolate and licks from the espresso press.  Cinder and ash fill in the periphery as dry bitterness suckles the back attachments of the tongue.  Fanatically black  in flavor, in fire, and in force.  Charming devilry, maintaining a medium-to-fuller body with a bitter black licorice line dragged through burnt rubber on asphalt.  Scorched cocoa is a generate of the coffee bitterness and black patent balance, trailing into bittersweet misgivings amidst stark chocolate bricks and charred crème brûlée.

On tap at the brewery, July 2005.  Wondrously opaque and black in color.  Deepest tan, creamy head Ive ever seen.  Smell is fantastic - charcoal, dark chocolate, burnt malts and charred crusted peppers.  Holy hell, weve achieved nirvana.  Complimentary bitter notes dance atop the finest barista blended espresso and dark chocolate flavors.  Singed, earthy and laden with the dark elements.  Absolutely to die for.  Ill revisit this rating after having it from the bottle to see if this rating should be bumped up or down...

thanks to Heemer77 for the bottle.  looks like used motor oil as I pour this bad boy into my glass.  aromas and flavors of deep, dark roasted malt, dark molasses, coffee and a bitter, not quite bittersweet, finish.  medium mouthfeel, yet it coats the tongue with the bitter roasted coffee finish.  not quite sweet enough for my taste but still a very well done porter.
Strong smokiness, very milky. Very good, though. I will buy and drink more.. and more.. and more.. and more..  This may become one of my more favored darks.

Aroma:  smoke, dark malts, dirt/earthiness, tobacco, some mustiness, and old milk

Appearance:  very dark brown, tan head, some lacing

Flavor:  cigarette ashtray taste, some cream, some semi-sweet chocolate, some tree bark, earthiness, smokiness

Palate:  smooth, slight bubbly, some smokey semi-sweet chocolate aftertaste

Overall:  not a bad beer, the ashtray flavor is not very appealing though.

Rich, milky and smoky cream and burnt smoking malts and wood in the aroma, a really magnificent creation... perhaps a little too harsh on the smoke, but the pure milk chocolate presense is enough to win me over.  Fresh, smoky and slightly harsh wood flavor, prickly on the tongue, with an appreciated bite and "youth" to it all... like I can taste the wood itself.  Finish contains more of the milk chocolate that was noted in the aroma, along with a mild butterscotch.  A very pleasing beer to drink, and worthy of it’s high marks.  The oreo cookie notes in the nose are something surprising.
nice tight black bdy with a weird lacy head.  aroma was very roasted and malty like a chocolate malt.  very sweet and some mocha hints.

Pours with a black body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet yet bitter with roasty and anice notes, as well as, some fruit notes.  The flavor is very roasty and bitter with a slight sweetness and a little coffee in the finish.  Medium to full bodied, smooth and a touch tingly.

Rich, dry, dark chocolate aroma. Fully opaque body. Light brown head; quickly diminishing. Excellent porter. This brew was a little too cold when I started, and although I could immediately sense its quality, the flavors are only now coming out with a few minutes of warming. Really, perfectly balanced. Has some solid bitterness, which to me is essential in a top porter. Wow, is this good and I am continually shocked at how different beers can taste at different temps. I can still imagine a better porter, but this is certainly up there.

12 oz Bottle:  Poured an oily textured opaque black, with a smallish fading tan head.  Aromas were amazing, big nose of coffee/espresso, roasted malts, slight earthiness, and sweet vanilla notes in the background.  Definately made me excited to take a sip.  Flavor doesnt disappoint in the least, balanced with a lot going on.  Up front are what you would expect after smelling this one, lots of coffee and other roasted flavors, but out of nowhere come the hops (slightly overbalanced with the malted characteristics but appreciated none the less).  The balance doesnt end there however, even into the dry hop finish, which lingers then disappears to reveal the espresso notes present  long after swallowing.  Mouthfeel was very soft and full.  Dark Horse finally brews something in the same league as their IPAs.

Pours black with very little carbonation.  Slight ring of a head appears on the outside of my glass.  Malt nose immediately present, coffee, roastiness.  Not much on the hop side in this bottle.  A bit uninspired, but could be different with a bit more carbonation.

This rating is overdue, and a nice one for number 400.  Poured a dark blackish color with a small tan head.  Nose is a ton of coffee, lotsa roasty malts too.  Flavor is bitter roasted malts, nice hop bitterness to balance things slightly.  Full bodied and smooth...I really like the coffee all the way through this one.   Nice dry finish....great ale!

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2010 Retrying this about five years later, now there is carbonation but the beer has sort of an over-tart character that is now what detracts from it. Honestly, I think the godawful graphic design on this label means this sits too long and you end up w/ old bottles. 

I wasnt expecting this to be so strong. Pours an oily black with only a wisp of head. Nose is big and rich with a bit of coffee, chocolate and a hoppy sort of funk. Lack of carbonation creates the  impression of thinness wich really detracts from the overall richness. Taste follows aroma mostly with a touch of astringency. It smells and tastes really nice but the weak carbonation really kills it. Too bad. 3.3
Pours black with a small tan head.  Smells of coffee, nutmeg and prunes.  Tastes of chocolate, roses and coffee.  Nice, but lacking in the mothfeel.

Black body with a dark orange head. The aroma is sweet maple and coffee with some roasted peanuts. Rich aroma. The taste is toasted peanuts and burnt coffee. Plenty of roasted flavors. If you like roasted tastes that arent quite smoke or coffee, this would be a good beer for you.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 12 fl oz. brown bottle, courtesy of heemer77. Opaque pour, brown-black colour, tiny tan head. Light roasted aroma. Big mouthfeel with huge roasted malt flavour, some sweetness and black coffee and cocoa notes. Lasting bittereness.

Bottle shared with my brother. Thanks for this one!!  Extremely pleasant sweet milk-chocolatey aroma.  This can be smelled easily from afar.  Awesome!  Closer inspection of the aroma reveals more roastiness with slight oak notes.  Magnificent!  Opaque, pitch black color with a brown head and gorgeous lacing.  Start is somewhat ill-defined, turning extremely roasted in the middle.  Coffe-like with mild astringent oakiness to finish.  DOesnt have the sweetness that the inital nose promises, but this is still very coffee-like and EXTREMELY ENJOYABLE.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate), lightly hoppy (flowers), with a light note of vanilla.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.

Very nice, but my socks stayed on.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2008 Bottle... Opaque, pitch black ale with a large, frothy, beige head. Terrific retention with good, creamy lacework. Milk chocolate and vanilla nose. Tastes like a NYC chocolate egg cream up front. Metallic, bitter as all hell and burnt to a crisp on the backside... acetic as well. Medium-bodied and creamy with mild carbonation. Charred, bitter finish. Quality brew. Thanks go out to eyedrinkale for the bottle!
I was very surprised by the rich flavor of this beer, It was recommended by a beer store.  This is one of my all time favorite beer!

opaque pour with a nice light brown head, but the head disappears fast.  Roasted malt aroma, vanilla, dirt...has a nice smell of the outdoors.  Nice bitterness to start, good amount of roasted malt, some mild chocolate sweetness.  Beautiful bitterness to finish, nice mouthfeel, very dry.  Full plate here, this is a wonderful beer, and I am glad to have had the chance to sample this.

Vicious deep black pour, creamy mocha colored head.  Nose held nice notes of espresso, roasted milk chocolate, whispers of vanilla, light ruby port, toast, and hints of earthiness.  It was very well balanced with burnt chocolate malt notes up front, and a nice bitter hop bite in the end.  Definite alcohol undertones with each sip were  noted.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, smooth, Sahara dry, bittersweet finish.  Dark Horse knows the black ale very well, but this is certainly no porter in my book!  I would put it more along the lines of a dry imperial stout.  With that being said, still a very good brew...

Tan head and a dark caramel-brown body. Aroma and flavor are of rich chocolate, caramel, and dark fruit. This is a sweet, creamy, and delicious porter. Has the nice house signature for this brewery and is my favorite of the 3 "dark" Dark Horse beers sampled.

Berries, prunes and raisins with a fair roastiness and some alcohol apparent to the nose.  Pours a very inky black with a dark brown cover of head that recedes rapidly to a thin veil and ring.  Coffee and chocolate flavours spar to a draw with a charred, burnt roastiness coming out in the finish.  Strong berry-like fruitiness and spicy, orange hop flavour throughout with a malt body that nicely supports the roasty bitterness.  Lasting sweetness and roasted malt flavour in the aftertaste.  Full-bodied and sticky with moderate carbonation.  Bottle (trade Nov. 2004).  Thanks, Silphium!

Deep opaque black body with a very large head more in the realm of a brown, rather than tan in color.  Perfect appearence.  Deeply roasted nose with hints of coffee mainly, and a touch of chocolate and blackberries.  Taste follows suit with an explosion of roasted grains (chocolate, coffee), fruits and a mild hop bitterness.  A tasty one for sure.

I had no idea what this beer was, poured a thick oil black with a tall tan head. This thing is swimming with alcohol in the taste and aroma, aside from that theres some big roasty coffee, almost burnt tasting, and some prune flavor. A very big and bitter beer that doesnt try to hide any of its alcohol.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2009 Another big thanks to footbalm for this.  .Pours obsidian with two-finger tan head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate malt, rich chocolate syrup, some coffee, some gym shorts, hops, prunes, licorice, Lucky Charms cereal (the first 3 aromas make up 75% of the aroma here).  Tastes roasty toasty dark malty, with big chocoff, some rauchiness, some licorice, some blackberries.  I figured this for an Impy stout, or an elite regular stout.  As a porter, it is among the all time pantheon of greatness.  As good as many Impy stouts Ive had (or better), and just as rich and complex!  Better than Dogwood Impy Porter, which had been my favorite porter thus far.  Just astounding!!!

bottle-again, hats off to jtw for sending this fine porter.  pours pitch black with a small tan head.  looks like most breweries oatmeal/sweet stouts!  This beer was not as viscus as the previous 4 stouts  i have had from this brewery, but much thicker than the thirsty trout porter.  Aromas of coffee, piney hops, earthy, chocolate and a touch of toffee.  nice flavors of roast, char, chocolate, and earthy hops, which is the first time i have detected hops in their dark beers.  again, shitloads of black patent malts (this brewery must have bags of this stuff stacked to the celling!).  palate is full and slingtly oily like all their dark beers.  a fantastic porter that im glad i have another bottle.  This brewery needs to get their website running again sometime soon!!!

much thanks to the man clarkw for this reserve porter.the dark horse poured black with a nice chocolate looking head that faded quickly.the aroma i gathered was a bit of coffee,some chocolate,and a bit of alcohol.damn the mouthfeel on this is outstanding!nice and thick with a good coating on the tounge.the flavor is top notch as well.chocolate,coffee,malts,and a bit of brownies at the end.this is a serious porter.

Opaque black with a toght small tan head. Massive chocolate aroma, The flavor is alos massive choclate with lots of burnt grains, quite bitter with a good amount of grapefruit. Medium full body dry finish with alcohol warming. I guessed it was an Imperial Stout not knowing the style. This is a mighty big porter.
Bottle:  Aroma is all black coffee and light cream.  Dark brown, virtually black with a tan head.  Flavor is all black coffee and very light cream.  Pretty big hop finish.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2005 My first Dark Horse.  It was as black and shiny as Founders Breakfast Stout, just beautiful.  Awesome combo of stout roastiness and porter sticky-sweetness.  Alcohol is a little high, but only because I want to drink a bunch of these.  Note: I think Dark Horse needs to provide more info (or any) about their beers either on the pack or the label.
Uh.. black.  Chocolate milk head.  Roasty slightly smoky nose.  Flavor is rich dark malt, cocolate.  Sweetish finish.  Rock.

Trade with Btg (thanks Ben). Man, this is a great looking beer. Solid black with a thick, brown head. Aroma is bitter-sweet chocolate and sour milk. The tastse starts off pure, rich and bitter coffee grounds made with a quality coffee and plenty of roasted malts. Taste also has some toast as well with a nice lingering hop bitterness. As creamy of a porter thats out there. The head lasts all the way through and leaves some lingering lacing. Well done indeed.
it almost smells creamy, it tastes really dry, its great to take big gulps but you can realy feel at the back of your tounge

This pours out like motor oil. Thick, black, with a thin tan head that disappeared quickly. Smells of alcohol, wood, chocolate, espresso. Kind of sweet with a very nice dark bitter coffee finish. Nice but really cant drink too many of them I think.

Black body, brown head, syrupy alcohol nose, sweet and chocolately, dry hoppy finish, alcohol bite, sediment settle at the bottom of the glass, kind of a strange porter really, Id call it a strong ale

Pours black, with no light able to pass through, and a medium tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and roasty.  Flavor is sweet and chocolatey.  Starts out like mild chocolate and then turns to a bittersweet chocolate.  Creamy and full bodied.  Warming sensation on the finish.

Pours a rich dark molasses with a thick brown head.  Aroma is sweet and complex, full of dark fruits and caramel.  Starts rich and sweet with great balance and a touch of bitterness toward a semi-dry roasty finish.  This is very reminiscent of an imperial stout, without much alcohol presence.  A very nice porter!  Thanks wohlfs and secret santa for this brew!
Bottle, nice brown head, nice lacing, dark brown/black in color, nice aroma of grains and coffee, nice taste of grain and hops with mild bitterness on tongue at the end.  nice beer.

12 oz bottle (thanks Sammy) ..Decanted into my tulip glass a black, light shedding, viscous ale with a beautiful creamy 3 finger cap that stacks out of the glass and remains....a pure joy to look at. 

Aromas are complex: burnt treacle malts, chicory, limes, hazel.

Starts with large roasted malts balanced with the ample lime-like citrus hops...then the middle settles on the tongue and departs a layered impression: chicory, Madera, molasses, nuts...all over seen with the lime hops...the finish is long with the chicory molasses tastes giving way to the increased bittering...finally a deep metallic aftertaste and a slow warming....the alcohol is well buried in this rich brew...wadda stout!! recommended!

Deep and dark brown with a thin head, but nice and loose lace. Very roasted grain flavors. Some dark chocolate, too. Mild sweetness. Healthy bitterness. Tasty, lingering dark roasted flavors and aromas.

Pours dark brown with a red tint, but sits black with a thin brown cream head.  Aroma is roast malt and milasses.  Flavor is spectacular.  Hits you in the mouth with a strong crisp malt and a viscous mouthfeel.  After the crispness, partially from the alcohol, it gets sweet and does end with that note of sugarry molasses.  A winning brew in my book.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 Dark red, purple color. No head. Very sweet candied malt aroma. Big roasted taste, get bitter. Some bit burnt malt tastes coming through as well. Sweet in the finish. Slight alcohol sting.

Bottle.  Pours a deep black color.  Nice brown head with nice lacing.  Aroma is all of roasted grains.  Full bodied, smooth mouthfeel.  Somewhat dry.  Lots of deeply roasted grains, black patent stands out.  Hops are very noticable but do not overpower the malt.  Very nicely done beer.

Bottle pours pitch black, large rocky light brown head, light sediment in the bottom of the glass, with fairly good lacing.   Heavily roasted malts, soy, light hops, and minor cocoa on the nose.   Smells quite delicious.   WOW, thats quite heavy for a porter.   Malts are good and burnt, hops are subtle but tasty, and the cocoa is unsweetened and slightly dry.   With the bit of soy mixed in, its like a Dry/Sweet/Imperial Stout crossed with a Porter.   Wonderful body, great mouthfeel.   This brew is rather hefty, so be prepared.   A nice warming bitterness on exit, along with mild cocoa, and again fairly dry.   Pretty tasty!   Thanks goes out to ClarkVV for the trade!

Entirely opaque black. Creamy and persistent light bronze foam. Colossal aroma of cocoa, espresso, ink, and blackberries. Hint of earthy black malt and developing  phenols. Tight, velvety carbonation. Slick body. Fresh cocoa and coarse roasty flavors atop a cocoa and rich espresso bedding. Trace oxidation.  Intensely acrid, throughout, with burnt matchsticks and seared  black malts. Attains most of its bitterness from the brisk char, which also creates a drying effect, while highlighting the espresso and muted hop presence. Bittersweet chocolate briefly offsets the acridness. Extremely woody finish of salted licorice and burnt black chocolate. Perhaps the most burnt-flavored Stout Ive ever tasted. Hardly a Porter, but more of an Imperial Stout than anything else. Either way, its a glorious brew, despite the phenols and oxidation.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Oooo! The smell wafts out, right from the second the crown is uncapped, and it smells gooood! Time for a closer inspection...
utter blackness in appearance, with a lush brown, creamy, cocoa-y head...as Freddie Prinz would say, "Looo-keeen gooood!" (Oh, I date myself...thats FP, Sr., of course...)
Smell it...ooooh, again! Rich and roasty, fine and toasty, nearly burnt, aburst with dark flavors, anise and maple and more... 
Huge mouthfeel, full bodied all the way, bittersweet, and terrifically complex. Little bit fruity, but very dry, this is rich, rewarding, very, very tasty.
Sampled this beer at the Great Taste of the Midwest in Madison WI.  Wow, beautiful color, and tasty.  Big fan of this ale.

Pours very dark, brown head. Roasty aroma, some light chocolate, also some hops. Flavor is pretty chocolaty, lightly sweet, some roast, followed by some coffee and hoppy bitterness. Medium to full body, alcohol is hidden well. Very nice.

Opaque black in color with a decent brown head.  The aroma is all roasted malt, and some sweetness.  Flavor follows suit, this beer is sweet and thick like a big boned chocolate porter.  Much thicker and roastier than I expected, yet it is a good beer.

Perpetual black, thick and opaque, sliced thin dark brown skim of a head, a thin collar remains mostly present; lacing in minimal strings and spots. 

Aroma is low-keyed and mellow with what seems to be quite a heft of black malt roastyness, partailly sweet with a mollasses undertone, hints of deep dark espresso beans and dark chocolate keep the nose happy. 

Sip....whoa! Wasnt expecting that! Wow, what a mega assault of blackened roasty stuff. Starts smooth and subdued with sweeter roasted malts with caramel, licorice, and molasses, then it gets all crazy with mega blackened malts and grains, earthy, smokey, charcoal effervescence and bittering coffee/espresso roast tones and pungent dry hop leaves. What an absolutely fantastic finish. That black roast makes itself a home across the entire palate. Oh so nice to let it just sit there and dry out the tongue. Its like taking a larger, fuller sip of espresso but its cold. Very nice appeal as far as thats concerned. The hops make for a nice meld in the finish as well. 

Feel is quick to start, slick creamy front, bold, richly robust, nearly full once it procedes past midway and the finish is a fuckin treat of roasty blackened stuff, very dry and coating with a long ever-lasting burntish quality. I may just be tasting this stuff the rest of the day. 

Stout, Schwartzbier, Black Bier Ale, or what ever they want to call this is fine by me, its awesome!

Not knowing what this style was from the label, I thought it was an imperial stout or something. Dark dirty oil pour, sparse fizzy light brown head. Aroma is a sweet dusty chocolate with some fruit. Excellent "pure chocolate-like" bitterness that matches some sweet fruits nicely. There is some chocolatey licorice in there as well. Thick, almost creamy mouthfeel and fairly soft carbonation. Good stuff!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2007 Id call this a tweaner - its maybe more of a stout than a porter.  Sweet malty caramel aroma with some roast or burnt notes.  Flavor is stoutish with roasts or smoke flavor coming through along with some hop bitterness and sweetness.  Full bodied for a porter.  Bitter sweet finish.

Looks like yummy chocolate drink. Stout roasted, with chocolate aroma. Creamy mouthfeel with roast. More so than coffee, which works for me. Enough of a drink experience, that you dont know the alcohol until..klunk.

Tan head swiftly recedes o a ring over this opaque black impressing hue. Powerful and appealing aroma. Impressively well blended and balanced, wait this is 8%? Smokey, roasted maple and gentle C-hops, grapefruity and lemony hit the nose together with molasses and licorice. Nothing overdone, nonetheless no flavor is shy. Dark malt comes out in a graham cookies and dark chocolate manner. C-Hops are just expressive enough to keep the focus and the malt interplay. Great mouthfeel with comfortable carbonation, as smooth as any oatmeal stout.. This is great psychprof..

Prevalent fruit under limitless C-hops...Molasses engulf the grassy bitterness with their viscous girth as dark chocolate and sinful roastiness smile gleefully...A heavy hymnodist of hearty harmonies...

A dark beer smell.  Coffee, carmel, malts, chocolate, dark dried fruits.  Amazing.  Black Bier?  Yuppers, could not see though this one.  A firm tan head that left some wonerful lacing too.  Lots of bitternes in the taste.  Burnt chocolates, and also some fruits.  I did manage to find some sweetness, but it was between the bitter beginning and the bitter finish.  A long drawn out finish.  Very tasty to drink and wonderful to look at.

What a surprise when the label says ale on it thats is what I thought I was getting. Glad I got a porter. poured dark brown with a deep tan frothy head good lacing.aroma was carmel, chocolate,dark fruitsfinish a nice bitterness with hints a sweetness glad I had to buy a 6 pack of this and not just 1 bottle which I like to do when I am trying out a new beer
Thick black poor, sweet, chocolate aroma, slightly bitter, but everything youd expect in a good, dark porter.

On tap at the brewery and the best among those that I rated. Poured a small sized thick head with fine sized bubbles that mostly diminished. The body was opaque and the hue was black. The aroma was mild coffee and chocolate with some fruityness noted. The flavor was lightly malty and coffee with a smooth mouthfeel. This was a very good beer in my opinion and I very much recommend giving it a try.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized mostly lasting dark brown colored bubbles that left behind a excellent lacing.  The body was opaque and dark black colored with no hope of seeing any carbonation.  The aroma was that of a big dark black beer with a lot of dark malts present.  The mouth feel was mild with a tingly start and then kicked in with a big malt bite in the finish.  The flavor was that of dark malts and a big black beer flavor.  very scrumptious and quite good.  Highly recommended and IMHO the best of their beers.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2004 2003 bottle. Pours extremely dark brown/black with lots of dark caramel/roasted colored head around the edges.  Bottle conditioned.  Small amount of head remains.  Smells very oily, thick roast and lightly chocolatey, with some fresh hops in the background.  Similar to the Oktoberfest in its abundant use of fresh moderately spicy hops, but unlike it in its extreme use of roasted barley.  Some mild, bitter chocolate notes and some sweeter sugary flavors as well.  The flavor was quite good with my biggest complaint being a bit too much thinning and some astringency from the dryness and flavor get a bit dull due to all of the roast.  Good offering for sure, though.  2003 bottle aged an additional number of months.  This one had the creamiest, most luxurious, velvety head Ive seen in a while.  Much more balanced than I rememeber, probably the hops flavor evening out.  Rich and smooth, but still has plenty of good roasty bitterness.  Seemed a touch thin on the end exacerbated by the huge bitterness, but I also drank this thing at about 65 degrees so that probably didnt help.  Uppin the score on this though, it deserves it.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2005 rerate, just a year after having it the first time. much smokier and coffee-intense than before (or perhaps just that i remember?)  surprisingly full finish despite the overall dryness of the beer.  has some lingering stickiness.  very nice.

original:  3.9   jet black with a thin tan head.  smells strongly of malt and chocolate, slightly smoky.  surprisingly hoppy, but extremely smooth with a coffee-like bitterness.  dry bitter finish.  this is pretty good!

Very nice black color,small tan head that lasted for only a short time.Nice roasted malt aroma with a hint of smoke to it,chocolate and a mild fruit come through as well.Malty taste with a nice dark espresso taste coming on with only a light chocolate,as it warms i notice the chocolate comeing on a little stronger and getting slightly sweeter with the coffee starting to mellow.The hops really come through nicely on this one,giving it a nice bitterness.the after taste is a nice bitter espresso that lasts for quite some time.This is a pretty decent brew and would be nice to have a few more.Thanks PsychProf

Pitch black brew that reveals nothing even when held to the light. Big cocoa colored head. Huge nose smelling of bitter chocolate and dark fruit. First taste reveals a slightly disappointing body. Thin and a bit watery.Flavors are bitter chocolate with some slight espresso notes. Some toffee hinting around also.A little bitterness in the finish is much appreciated. Very good beer, if only the body were more substantial.
Black beer with no head. Roasted, coffee and chocolade aroma. Light malty but with some bitterness. Dry tobacco aftertaste.

Bottle: O.K. Nose Coffee/chocolate. Black color poured with little head. Smokey, bakers chocolate, coffee, some molasses flavor. Creamy with a drawn out bitter finish. Good bier, just not what I think of with a black bier.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Black. Light brown head. Roasty, chocolaty aroma w/ some light nuts. Thick, oily feel. Roasty, nutty, chocolaty, coffee flavour. Decent bitterness. Perhaps a little too sweet.

murky almost black colour.  nice aroma of coffee and brown sugar.  very big and roasty with lots and lots of coffee flavour.  seems to drink more like a big porter rather than it's namesake black beer.  still, it's quite tasty.

Awesome opaque with scattered plum black colour. Faint smoked, coffee and mild bitter chocolate aroma. Medium thin body. Medium hops and stronger roasted malt with hints of golden syrup and overbrewed bitter coffee flavours.
(Bottle) Opaque with little head. Coffee and chocolate nose. Hops beating. Creamy. Too clean a finish. Very good.

(WCC2003) Motor oil black body with minimal brown head.  This is a coffee beer -- coffee aroma, coffee coffee taste.  Some hoppy bitterness too.  Medium full body.  Lots of coffee in this one.  Lots of coffee.

Wow! That's a roasted porter. Palate is a bit tangy, but smooth enough. Dark as sin with a roasted coacoa head. Overall a nice porter that is very chocolaty and quite smooth. Tastes and drinks like a stout.
Up front roasty earthy dark chocolate taste. Dark, looks purple at times. Creamy mouthfeel, long bitter finish that curls up the sides of the tongue.

Good complexity and flavors working with this one.  It is "jet black" and the flavor reflects the color -- dark caramel, toffee, coffee, roasted alcohol.  Well balanced by a bit o' hops to give it the right edge.  Worth the trip!

UPDATED: APR 1, 2005 Appearance: The bottle has a cartoon-ish drawing of a donkey on it. My daughter, who likes Eeyore, thought it was cool...
Otherwise: This is an imperial stout; Im not sure why bottle calls it a "black bier". 
It pours very thickly. The head is very thin, and brown colored. The flavors are roasty with a hint of hops. its nice tasting. Has some nice smokiness too

Wow - is this a porter, a stout or maybe an "Imperial Black Ale" - pitch black with a ring of espresso head on top.  Full of chocolate when cooler, then bitter cofee as it warms.  Also tastes fine with brownies.

MBG.  VEry dark brown with a small tan head.  Bitter roasted malt aroma up front with a hop background.  Taste of slight coffee and chocolate.  Slightly bitter, slight alcohol, yet smooth for a 7% beer.

At MiBG Summer fest: Beautiful nearly opaque black with streaks of red, small but solid tan head. Aroma had hints of smoke, espresso, bittersweet chocolate, molasses, and nuts. Taste was a wonderful tartness with full smokey and raisin sweet roundness. Nutty and coffee dryness balanced everything perfect. Soft and oily mouthfeel for this full-bodied beer. Highly recommended.

Heres' a beer with a lot going on!!! Big and black, with hops jumping out in the nose, but also chocolate, molasses, anice, coffee bean.  These flavors are rich in the middle as well as some caramel shining through. Much more molasses and anice from the bottle. Nice balance all around, roasty and dry at the end. Chocolate lingers. Yum, go have this at their pub!!!!

MIBG Fest: Thick brown colour with a tan head. Rich and appealing chocolate malt aroma. Great notes of chocolate, coffee, licorice and malt in the flavour, balanced in the finish with a healthy dose of hops. Excellent stuff.

Deep black in colour.  Aroma is very roasty, malty, with some dark chocolate and licorice.  The flavour has a lot going on.  First off its the strong dark chocolate flavour.  Then the coffee roastness and the malty bitterness kicks in.  Finishes very long and bitter.  Many thanks to PsychProf for sending this my way.

Fits nicely with the Dark Horse stout line.  I remember enjoying this one in my undergrad days, and finding a 6-pack (finally) was a pleasant surprise.  Pours molasses-dark, with a tan/brown head.  Aroma is potent roasted chocolate with an essence of malt sugars.  Likewise, the flavor is of rich roasted chocolate, coffee, black licorice, and burnt slightly sweet malts.  Finishes dry.  A real winner.  The black licorice and molasses notes are characteristic of the Dark Horse dark beers.  Get your hands on them if you can.  I especially recommend this one to fans of Bells Kalamazoo Stout.  I'll have to pick up that Smoked Stout I left in the store...

Very dark opaque black color with a good sized thick beige head. The aroma was sweet, roasted, mildly fruity (yes this is a porter) and towards the end slightly nutty and smoky. The flavor was very full, well rounded...roasted grain, coffee, smoky, nutty, alcohol , and some chocolate with a huge smoky aftertaste. The feel was thick, but crisp...perfect. Outstanding beer!

(On tap at DHBC) Dark, bitter (it has quite a bite, no pun intended :), creamy, luscious, and CLEAN, REALLY CLEAN for such a dark, substantial brew.  And a wonderful surprise in the aroma - olives!  This is a good quality porter.  Definitely recommended.
Great robust flavor.  This beer (whatever style you want to call it) has a sweetness that really masks its 8% ABV.  Very well balanced - you could drink more than you probably should.

Ultra-black, ultra-thick creamy brown head; this one really looks like a milkshake folks.  Big roasty bitter-chocolate nose.  Flavor is a nice mix of bitter roasted nuts and coffee, and chocolaty sweetness.  On the whole, perhaps a bit too hard on the tongue for me, but the power of this beer is not to be denied.  Intensely bitter and dry finish, good thick creamy body; overall very very good.  Thanks Psychprof Michael!

Pitch black with an oily ruddy tan head.  Lots of espresso and dark chocolat in the nose.  Slightly sweet with pleanty of chewy dark choolate in the mouth, hints of berries and that certain Dark Horse coolness in the mouthfeel.  Finishes nice and dry with tons of roastiness.  Thank you psychprof.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2005 Thick dark pour w/ a dark tan to brown head.  Roasty, bourbony aroma with a background of fudge.  Big carbination, a big, huge roast character.  Somewhat smokey, extremely roasty and an ending of bitter chocolate.  A little milky too...it would be better with less carbination.

Wow, have you ever had really strong coffee that some jackass declared excellent and you just shake your head and say next time I'll make the coffee.  So as you have to face this stong coffe you dread every sip, and eventually it gets cold.  So there it sits after two hours of waiting to be drank, and you finally get enough nuts screwed up in yourself to drink it.  So here goes!  Your first thought as you drink away is; wow this is still really strong coffee.  The second is that; wow this coffee is really cold.  So you gulp it down and slam the glass to the counter and yell out a blood curdling war cry in defiance.  After composing yourself you notice the acidic aftertaste and assume a puckered face.  That is the feeling I got with this beer, but suprisingly I wanted more after a drained the bottle.  Thanks Psych_prof for a good porter to describe.

Delicious. This pours out black in the glass with an aroma of chocolate, lightly of black licorice and coffee. The taste is complex, with roasted, burnt malt, chocolate, and coffee. A nice dose of hops on the finish. This seemed more like a stout than a swartzbier, but hey, its a highly drinkable beer whatever the style may be.

From Psych Profs cellar comes this tremendous beer.  Completely black with very nice rust head that lasts.  Big toasted nose with some hops.  Rich flavor framed perfectly by the espresso grain.  Fruitiness blends in so nicely for a very complex stout.  Porter?  No, I dont allow "porter" to be completely opaque.  Stout all the way.  Excellent beer.  Many thanks to Psych Prof.

A great fucking beer, prolly my favorite porter.  Whats with the yellow-eyed ass on the label though?  Roasty sweet aroma, notes of hops.  Excellent taste, perfectly balanced....seemed a bit sweet for the style, but it rocked....as the taste alternated from coffee to hoppy sweetness.....well done.

Hmmm - I like this.  Im usually not a fan of huge raosted action or the darker, more bitter coffee type flavours, but this one has a caramel or chocolate undertone that gives me enough to chew on while Im sorting out those dominant bitters.

Very nice roasty stout.  Jet black with a large, brown head that dissipated fairly quickly.  Aroma contains coffee, earthy hops and bitter chocolate.  Loaded up with flavors of dark coffee, bitter chocolate, hops and toffee.  Malty and roasty up front giving way to an astringent, hoppy finish.  Nice, thick body.  Impressive (porter???).  Thanks, PsychProf!
dark as night, wonderful big creamy dark head, roasted chocolate malt aroma and taste with hints of caramel and coffee, nice bitter hop finish, a nice beer

The beer pours darker than the inside of a cow!. Head is colossal, creamy, the lace sticky thick sheets that cling mightly to the glass, both are a nice chocolate color. Nose is coffeeish, roasted grains, caramel, with hints of malt, very sniffable. The start is malt and somewhat sweet, the top is bulky, the finish is ponderously hopped, scantily carbonated, the aftertaste aridly dry and long lasting. Very quaffable beer, and a nice way to start the weekend, also well worth your trying. Ranks #338 on my current 1000 beer master list.

Opaque black, nice tan, long-lasting head.  Coffee smell and flavor, its almost a stout.  Full-bodied, some bittering hops toward the middle that last into the finish, sall good!  Dorky label, as pointed out by others.  Thanks to PsychProf for sending this beer to everyone else and giving my rating some good company!

Expected something along the lines of a Schwarzbier, got a big meaty stout. Nice, thick, black beer with a big dirty-brown head. Strong roasted malt aroma and flavor. Thick body. Creamy. Not a ton of hops. Some bitterness. Sketchiest label ever! Glue smeared all around the edges of the label. One of the bottles on the shelf had two labels on a bottle with the top covering a screw-up on the bottom label. My drinking companions and I wondered why the hell there would be a goofy looking donkey on the label until we realized that it must be the "dark horse" that the brewery was named after. Possibly produced using stock clip-art on an Apple ][e. But a nice beer.

Deep dark brown in color ... resembles a porter or stout.  Tons (too many in my opinion) of suspended yeast blobs.  Flavor is dominated by roasted malts ... I have had dry stouts with less roasted flavor!  Rich and buttery, but not that impressive as a whole.

Nice chocolate and coffee aroma with a strong roasted malt finish.  A bit of an overshoot on the roasted malt though... which tends to override the complexity of the beer.  I think I need a sample from on-premise to back up my review.  Lets go...

Strong roasty plummy aroma.  Very dark opaque black, and extra dark brown head.  Rich roasty flavor with dry med bitter finish.  Smooth.  Some chocolate notes in there too.  I cant believe this was really 8%?  Its definitely one of the boldest stouts Ive ever had.

Dark jet black color, roasted coffee aroma, black burnt plum-coffee flavor, very burnt,dry and bitter lasting finish. I put my money on this Dark Horse, this is a winner! Thanks PsychProf for this underrated killer beer.
